14.18: Truly a great mountain falls, and a rock moves out of its place.
14.19: The waters wear away the stones and wash away the soil of the earth; so thou destroyest the hope of man.
14.20: Thou prevailest for ever against him, and he passes; thou castest him away with shame on his face.
14.21: If his sons multiply, he does not know it; if they decrease, he perceives it not of them.
14.22: But his flesh upon him shall have pal,, and his soul within him shall mourn.

15.1: THEN answered Eliphaz the Temanite, and said,
15.2: Should a spiritually minded man answer with knowledge and then become enraged?
15.3: Should he admonish with unprofitable talk, or with words that are worthless?
15.4: Yea, you also are discarding reverence, and talk too much in the presence of God.
15.5: For your mouth is accustomed to utter sinful things, and you choose the deceitful tongue of the crafty.
15.6: Your own mouth condemns you, and not I; yea, your own lips testify against you in my presence.
15.7: Are you the first man that was born? Or were you conceived before the hills?
15.8: Have you heard of the secrets of God? Has his wisdom been revealed to you?
15.9: Or what do you know that we do not know? Or what do you under, stand that we do not understand?
15.10: Behold, there are among us the gray-headed and the very aged men, much older in days than your father.
15.11: Now talk less of God's threats, and speak comfortingly to yourself.
15.12: Why does your heart boast? And what do your eyes wink at,
15.13: That you boast in the presence of God, and let such words go out of your mouth?
15.14: What is man, that he should be innocent? Or he that is born of a woman, that he should be righteous?
15.15: Behold, he puts no trust in his saints; yea, the heavens are not clean in his sight.
15.16: Even though man should be rejected and afflicted, yet he shall drink iniquity like water.
15.17: Hear me, I will show you; and that which I have seen I will repeat;
15.18: That which wise men have declared, and did not hide from their fathers;
15.19: To whom alone the land was given, and no stranger passed among them.
15.20: The wicked man magnifies himself all his days, and the number of the years of the violent man is hidden.
15.21: A dreadful sound is in his ears; in prosperity the spoiler shall come upon him.
15.22: He does not believe that he shall be overthrown because of the darkness, and that he shall see the sword.
15.23: He flees because of the threat of judgment; he does not know that the day of darkness is already at his hand,
15.24: Trouble and anguish shall overtake him, like a king ready for the battle,
15.25: Because he has stretched out his hand against God, and strengthened himself against the Almighty.
15.26: He runs against him proudly, and strangles him, with the multitudes of his shields;
15.27: Because he has deceived himself with his wealth, and he places Pleiades above Aldebaran.
15.28: And he dwells in desolate cities, which no man has inhabited; then he prepares for war.
15.29: He shall not continue, neither shall his strength endure, nor shall his words be established upon the earth.
15.30: He shall not depart out of darkness; the flame shall dry up his branches, and by the breath of his mouth shall he be rejected.
15.31: Let him not trust in deceptive vanity, for his growth is in vain.
15.32: He shall dry up before his time, and the work of his hands shall not be found.
15.33: He shall shake off his unripe grapes, as the vine, and shall cast off his flowers as the olive tree.
15.34: For the congregation of the godless shall be desolate, and fire shall consume the tabernacle of the wicked.
15.35: They conceive mischief and bring forth deceit, and their belly is full of guile.

16.1: THEN Job answered and said,
16.2: I have heard many such things; wicked comforters are you all.
16.3: Do not grieve my spirit with words; even though you speak, I will not answer.
16.4: I also could speak as you do; I wish you were in my place, then I could try you out with words, and shake my head at you.
16.5: I would prove you with your own words, and the words of my lips would not spare you.
16.6: If I speak, my pain is not assuaged; and if I forbear, who can comfort me?
16.7: But now he has troubled me, and yet has preserved all of my testimony.
16.8: Thou didst appoint me and I became a witness, but my lies have testified against me; and I spoke in his presence.
16.9: He has torn me and broken me in his wrath; he gnashes upon me with his teeth; my enemy sharpens his eyes against me.
16.10: They have gaped upon me with their mouth reproachfully; they have smitten me upon my cheeks; they were filled with rage against me.
16.11: God has delivered me to the ungodly, and turned me over into the hands of the wicked.
16.12: I was at ease, but he has smitten me; he has also taken me by my neck, and shaken me to pieces, and set me up for his target.
16.13: His arrows are round about me, he shoots at my kidneys and does not spare; he pours out my gall on the ground.
16.14: He breaks me with breach upon breach; he runs against me like a giant.
16.15: I have girded sackcloth upon my skin, and I have covered my head with dust.
16.16: My face is troubled with weeping, and on my eyelids is the shadow of death;
16.17: But not for any iniquity in my hands; my prayer also is pure.
16.18: O earth, cover not my blood, and let my cry have no place!
16.19: And now, behold, my witness is in heaven, and my acquaintances are on high.
16.20: O my brethren and my neighbors! my eyes pour out tears to God!
16.21: O that one might plead for a man with God, as a man pleads for his neighbor!
16.22: For the number of a man's years will come to an end; then he shall go the way from whence he shall not return.

17.1: MY spirit is weary, my days are extinct; the grave is ready for me,
17.2: For there is no falsehood in me, and yet my spirit dwells in their bitterness.
17.3: Make me, I pray thee, a hostage with thee; then I will surrender myself.
17.4: For thou hast hid their heart from understanding; therefore they shall exalt themselves in their deception.
17.5: When a friend behaves insolently toward his friend, even the eyes of his children shall fail.
17.6: He has granted power to the nations; I shall be derided before them.
17.7: My eye is dim because of anger, and all my senses are like a shadow.
17.8: Upright men shall be amazed at this, and the innocent shall stir himself up against the guilty.
17.9: The righteous also shall hold to his way, and he that has clean hands shall be stronger and stronger.
17.10: But as for you all, you are hypocritical, and yet you return and come to me; but I cannot find a wise man among you.
17.11: O you time wasters! Dawdlers! Who think about nothing! O you destroyers of the hearts of the people!
17.12: You change the night into day; and you bring forth the light before the darkness is over.
17.13: If I wait, Sheol is my house; I have made my bed in the darkness.
17.14: I have said to corruption, You are my father; to the worm, You are my mother and my sister.
17.15: Where is now my hope and my trust? As for my hope, who shall find it?
17.16: They shall go down to the bottom of Sheol; they shall descend together into the dust.

18.1: THEN Bildad, the Shuhite, answered and said,
18.2: How long will you resist words? Understand! and afterwards we will speak.
18.3: Wherefore are we counted as beasts, and have become abominable in your sight? O you who slays himself in his anger?
18.4: Shall the earth be forsaken for your sake? And shall the mountain be removed out of its place?
18.5: Yea, the lamp of the wicked shall be put out, and the spark of his fire shall not shine.
18.6: The light shall be dark in his tent, and his lamp above him shall be extinguished.
18.7: He shall be deserted in his illness, and his own counsel shall cast him down.
18.8: For he has stretched out his feet into the net, and lie walks upon a snare.
18.9: The trap seizes him by the heel, and thirst shall prevail against him.
18.10: A snare is laid for him on the ground, and a trap for him in his paths.
18.11: Terror shall make him afraid on every side, and shall drive him to his feet.
18.12: Let famine be his grief, let destruction be ready for his posterity.
18.13: Let force devour his towns, let his first-born die in violence.
18.14: His confidence shall be rooted out of his tent, and he shall be brought hastily by the king's executioner.
18.15: Others shall dwell in his tent, because there is no one in it; brimstone shall be scattered upon his habitation.
18.16: His roots shall be dried up beneath, and above shall his vintage be cut off.
18.17: His remembrance shall perish from the earth, and he shall have no name upon it.
18.18: He shall be driven from light into darkness, and chased out of the world.
18.19: He shall neither have name nor remembrance among the people, nor any survivor in his dwelling place.
18.20: They that come after him shall be astonished at his day, as they that went before them were terrified.
18.21: Surely such is the dwelling of the wicked, and this is the place of him who knows not God.

19.2: How long will you grieve my soul, and make me sick with words?
19.3: For behold, these ten times you have rebuked me; and yet you are not ashamed that you make me sad.
19.4: If indeed I have erred, my error remains with myself.
19.5: If you have justly magnified yourselves against me, rebuked me, and reproached me,
19.6: Know then that God has condemned me, and spread his net over me.
19.7: If I howl, no one answers me; and if I complain, there is no one to avenge me.
19.8: He has fenced up my ways so that I cannot pass, and he has set darkness in my paths.
19.9: He has stripped me of my glory, and taken the crown from my head.
19.10: He has destroyed me on every side, and I am no more; and my hope has he removed like a piece of tree.
19.11: He has also kindled his wrath against me, and he counts me as his enemy.
19.12: His messengers have come together against me; they debated their ways against me, and encamped round about my tent.
19.13: My brothers are far off from me, and my acquaintances have deserted me.
19.14: My kinsfolk have failed me, and my familiar friends have forsaken me.
19.15: They that dwell in my house, and my maids, consider me as a stranger; I am an alien in their sight.
19.16: I called my servant, and he gave me no answer; I entreated him with my mouth and implored him.
19.17: I have become a stranger to my wife, and have implored the children of my own body.
19.18: Yea, even the wicked despise me; when I rise, they speak against me.
19.19: All my counselors abhor me; even my friends have turned against me.
19.20: My skin and my flesh cleave to my bones, and I am escaped with the skin of my teeth.
19.21: Have pity upon me, have pity upon me, O you my friends; for the hand of God has been against me.
19.22: Why do you also persecute me like God, and you are not satisfied with the hurt of my flesh?
19.23: Oh that my words were now written! Oh that they were inscribed in a scroll!
19.24: That they were engraved with an iron pen on lead or in the rock for ever!
19.25: For I know that my Saviour lives, and at the end he will reveal himself upon the earth;
19.26: Although devouring worms have covered my skin and my flesh,
19.27: Yet, if my eyes shall see God, then my heart also will see the light; but now my body is consumed.
19.28: For you will say, Why did we persecute him? For a good report will follow me and vindicate me.
19.29: Spare yourselves from the sword; for the wrath of sinners is a sword; for you shall yet know that there is judgment.

20.1: THEN Zophar, the Naamathite, answered and said,
20.2: Therefore my discipline has caused me to discern, and for my help it has remained with me.
20.3: I will make you hear the instruction of my discipline, and the spirit of my understanding will cause me to answer.
20.4: This I know from of old, since man was created upon the earth,
20.5: That the triumphing of the wicked is short, and the joy of the godless but for a moment.
20.6: Though his excellency mount up to the heavens and his head reach to the clouds,
20.7: Yet he shall perish for ever like a whirlwind; those who have seen him shall say, Where is he?
20.8: He shall fly away like a dream, and shall not be found; yea, he shall be chased away like a vision of the night.
20.9: The eye also which saw him shall see him no more; neither shall they see his place again.
20.10: His children shall be crushed with poverty, and he shall stretch out his hands toward them.
20.11: His bones are full of marrow, but they shall lie down with him in the dust.
20.12: Though his wickedness is sweet in his mouth, though he hide deceit under his tongue,
20.13: Though he spare it and forsake it not, but keep it still in his mouth;
20.14: Yet his food in his stomach is turned, it is the gall of asps within him.
20.15: The riches which he had swallowed down, he shall vomit up out of his belly; and God shall destroy him.
20.16: He shall suck the poison of asps; the tongue of an adder shall slay him.
20.17: He shall not see the rivers, the floods, the brooks of honey and butter.
20.18: That which he had labored for shall he restore, and shall not swallow it down; that which he had acquired by extortion he shall not enjoy;
20.19: Because he has thought to forsake the poor; because he has violently taken away a house which he did not build.
20.20: Because he knew no justice himself, he shall not be spared by his covetousness.
20.21: There shall none of his posterity be spared; therefore his good will not be remembered.
20.22: With the measure with which he had measured, he shall be recompensed; the hand of the wicked shall come upon him.
20.23: May his posterity go to destruction, may God cast the fury of his wrath upon him, and deluge him while he wars against him.
20.24: For although he had escaped because of the breastplate of iron, the bow of brass shall pierce him through.
20.25: It is drawn, and it brings forth his inward parts; and the skin of his gall shall be pierced; terror shall be upon him continually.
20.26: All darkness is kept in store for his posterity; a blazing fire shall consume him; and the one who is left in his tent shall be destroyed.
20.27: The heaven shall reveal his sins; and the earth avenge itself upon him.
20.28: The foundations of his house shall be left bare and he shall be scourged in the day of his wrath.
20.29: This is the portion of a wicked man from God, and the heritage appointed to him from the Highest.

21.1: THEN Job answered and said,
21.2: Listen diligently to my speech, and let this be your consolation.
21.3: Suffer me that I may speak; and after I have spoken, then mock on.
21.4: I will utter my complaint to men, why my spirit is distressed.
21.5: Return to me, and be astonished, and lay your hand upon your mouth.
21.6: Even when I think of it, I tremble, and terror takes hold of my flesh.
21.7: Why do the ungodly live, and why are the mighty in power full of years?
21.8: Their descendants are established in their sight with them, and their children before their eyes.
21.9: Their houses are safe from fear, neither is the rod of God upon them.
21.10: Their bull breeds, and fails not; their cow calves, and does not cast her calf.
21.11: Their children stand firm like a flock, and their boys dance.
21.12: They take the timbrels and harps, and rejoice at the sound of singing.
21.13: They spend their days in prosperity, and then suddenly go down to Sheol.
21.14: They say to God, Depart from us; for we do not desire to know thy ways.
21.15: Moreover, they say, Who is God, that we should serve him? And what would we gain, that we should pray to him?
21.16: Lo, they have no power over their prosperity; the counsel of the ungodly is far from me.
21.17: How often is it that the wicked are left without an heir! how often their destruction comes upon them! God distributes sorrows in his anger.
21.18: They are like straw before the wind, and like chaff that the storm carries away.
21.19: God reserves man's iniquity for his children; he pays it back to him, and he shall know it.
21.20: His eyes shall see his destruction, and he shall drink of the wrath of the Almighty.
21.21: For what pleasure has he in his house after him, when a portion of his years shall be reserved for his posterity?
21.22: Shall any teach God knowledge, seeing it is he who judges the proud?
21.23: One dies in his full strength, sound of body, being wholly confident, and at ease.
21.24: His body is full of fat, and his bones are filled with marrow.
21.25: And another dies in the bitterness of his soul, never having tasted prosperity.
21.26: They shall lie down in the dust, and the worms shall cover them.
21.27: Behold, I know your thoughts, and the devices which you wrongfully imagine against me.
21.28: For you say. Where is the house of the righteous? And where is the place in which the wicked has pitched his tent?
21.29: Have you not asked those who pass by the way? And do you not recognize their tokens?
21.30: For the evil man is reserved for the day of destruction, he shall be remembered in the day of wrath.
21.31: Who can show him the way? And who shall repay him for what he has done?
21.32: Yet he shall be brought to the grave, he is reserved for misfortune.
21.33: The depths of the valley shall swallow him, and many shall be drawn in after him, even as there are innumerable ahead of him.
21.34: How then can you comfort me in vain, seeing that your abominable answers are multiplied before me?

22.1: THEN Eliphaz, the Temanite, answered and said,
22.2: O man, can you converse with God; are you equal with him in wisdom?
22.3: What do you profit by trying to make it seem that your ways are perfect because you are afraid?
22.4: He will reprove you, and enter into judgment with you.
22.5: Behold, your wickedness is great, and there is no end to your sins.
22.6: For you have taken a pledge from your brothers for nothing, and stripped the naked of their clothing.
22.7: You have not given water to the weary to drink, and you have withheld bread from the hungry.
22.8: There is a man who sows a field for himself, and the mighty man seizes it from him by force.
22.9: You have sent widows away empty, and the arms of the fatherless you have broken.
22.10: Therefore snares are round about you, and sudden fear causes you to tremble;
22.11: Where is the darkness, that you cannot see; and the flood of water that covers you?
22.12: Behold, God is in the height of heaven, and sees the highest of the stars that are very high.
22.13: And yet you say, How does God know? Can he judge through the thick darkness?
22.14: Thick clouds are a covering to him, so that men cannot see him; and he walks upon the circle of the heaven.
22.15: Have you marked well the old way which wicked men have trodden long ago?
22.16: Those who were cut down before their time, who were stopped at the crossing place of the river of life, and then did not remember who had laid down their pattern of living,
22.17: Who said to God, Depart from us; what can God do for us?
22.18: Yet he filled their houses with good things, and the counsel of the wicked kept away from them.
22.19: The righteous shall see it, and shall be glad; and the innocent shall laugh them to scorn.
22.20: If they are not prostrated because of their stubbornness, then their remnant shall be consumed with fire.
22.21: Make now an agreement with God, and offer to him of your good crops.
22.22: Receive the law from his mouth, and lay up his words in your heart.
22.23: If you shall repent before God, you shall be built up; if you shall put away iniquity from your dwelling place;
22.24: Then you shall lay up silver like dust, and the gold of Ophir as the sand of the valley.
22.25: Yea, God shall be your defense, and you shall have plenty of silver.
22.26: For then you shall lift up your face to God.
22.27: And you shall make your prayer to him, and he shall hear you, and you shall fulfill your vows.
22.28: You shall also decree a thing, and it shall be established for you; and the light shall shine upon your ways.
22.29: For it is said, He who humbles himself shall be exalted; and he who is meek shall be saved.
22.30: The innocent man shall be spared wherever he is, and he shall escape by the purity of his hands.

23.2: Even today is my complaint bitter; God's hand is heavier and increases my groaning.
23.3: Oh that I knew where I might find him, that I might come even to his seat!
23.4: I would lay my cause in order before him, and fill my mouth with arguments.
23.5: I would know what he would answer me, and understand what he would say to me.
23.6: Would he contend with me with his great power? If he would not, then he will put his fear into me.
23.7: There I might contend justly with him; and I might be justified and acquitted.
23.8: Behold, if he goes before me, I know not; or behind, I cannot perceive him.
23.9: I seek him on my left hand, but I cannot behold him; then I turn to my right hand, but I cannot see him.
23.10: But it is he who knows my way and my existence, and has tried me like gold, and I came forth pure.
23.11: My feet have held firm to his steps, and I have kept his ways.
23.12: I have not despised the commandments of his lips; neither have I departed from his will, and have kept the words of his mouth.
23.13: But in return for one of these, what has he granted me? What his soul desires, even that he does.
23.14: But he performs his covenant; and many such things are with him.
23.15: Therefore I am fearful at his presence; when I consider, I am afraid of him.
23.16: For God has troubled my heart, and my mind is confused:
23.17: Because I was not silenced before the darkness, and before the covering of the blackness.

24.1: WHY are the wicked not hidden from the presence of God, and why do those who know him never enjoy their days?
24.2: The wicked remove the landmarks; they violently take away a flock.
24.3: They seize the ass of the fatherless, they take the widow's ox for a pledge.
24.4: The wicked hide themselves beside the road, and the meek of the earth hide together.
24.5: Behold, like wild asses in the desert, they go forth early seeking food for their young ones.
24.6: They cut hay in a field which is not theirs; and they gather grapes from the vineyard of the wicked.
24.7: They cause the naked to lodge without clothing, and they have no covering in the cold.
24.8: They are wet with the showers of the mountains, and embrace the rock for want of shelter.
24.9: They take by force plunder of the fatherless, and they devour the poor.
24.10: They cause them to go naked without clothing, and they take away bread from the hungry,
24.11: Who are bent down under burdens during the reapers' banquets, and are hungry when they carry the large basket and the measure. At times they are hungry at the reapers' banquets; they tread the wine press, but they suffer thirst.
24.12: From the midst of the city the oppressed groan, and the souls of the wounded cry out; yet God does not accept their prayer.
24.13: They were in God's world; but they knew not his ways; nor did they walk in his paths.
24.14: The murderer arises at daylight, and kills the poor and needy, and in the night he is a thief.
24.15: The eyes also of the adulterer wait for the darkness, saying, No eye shall see me; and he disguises his face in the dark.
24.16: In darkness he breaks into houses which he has marked in the daytime. The wicked know not the light.
24.17: Therefore they sought for themselves the shadow of death, and have found it: yea, they are in the terrors of the shadow of death.
24.18: They are swiftly carried away upon the face of the waters; their portion is cursed in the earth; they behold not the familiar way of the vineyards.
24.19: Drought and heat consume the snow waters; for they have sinned in Sheol.
24.20: They have gone astray from the womb; the worm shall suck them; after death they shall be remembered no more; and the wicked shall be broken like a piece of wood.
24.21: An evil barren woman shall never bear; they do not good to the widow.
24.22: The wealth of a man of power is sustained by his own strength; he does not depend on divine guidance.
24.23: Though he be granted safety, wherein he has confidence, yet his eyes are upon his own evil ways.
24.24: Such men are exalted for a little while, but soon are no more; yea, all the provokers shall be brought low and destroyed; they wither and are shaken out like the heads of grain.
24.25: And if it is not because of his anger, then who will make me a liar, and make my speech worth nothing before God?

25.1: THEN Bildad, the Shuhite, answered and said,
25.2: Dominion and reverence are with him, he has made peace in his heavens.
25.3: Is there any number to his armies? And upon whom does not his light shine?
25.4: How then can man be justified with God? Or how can he be declared blameless, he who is born of a woman?
25.5: Behold, even the moon cannot be justified; yea, the stars are not pure in his sight.
25.6: How much less man, who is dust, and the son of man, who is a worm!

26.2: Why do you try to help him who is powerless? Why do you try to save the arm that has no strength?
26.3: How have you counselled him who has no wisdom? And how have you expounded so many doctrines?
26.4: To whom have you uttered words? And whose soul has come forth from you?
26.5: Behold, the mighty men shall be slain, and they shall lie down quieter than still waters.
26.6: Sheol is naked before him, and destruction has no covering.
26.7: He stretches out the north from the empty place, and hangs the earth upon nothing.
26.8: He binds up the waters in his thick clouds; and the cloud is not rent under them.
26.9: He holds fast the covering of the firmament, and spreads his cloud upon it.
26.10: He has circled the waters with bounds, until the day and night come to an end.
26.11: The pillars of heaven tremble and are astonished at his reproof.
26.12: He rebukes the sea with his power, and by his wisdom he saves many.
26.13: By his spirit he manages the heavens; his hand slew the fleeing serpent.
26.14: Lo, these are merely parts of his ways; and what evil thing have we heard against him? And the greatness of his might who can understand?

27.1: MOREOVER Job continued his parable, and said,
27.2: As God lives, who has wronged my judgment, and the Almighty, who has made my soul bitter;
27.3: As long as my soul is in me, and the spirit of God is in my nostrils;
27.4: My lips shall not speak wickedness, nor my tongue utter deceit.
27.5: God forbid that I should do evil, till I die I will not remove my innocence from me.
27.6: My righteousness I hold fast, and will not let it go; my heart shall not reproach me so long as I live.
27.7: Let my enemy be as the ungodly, and he that hates me as the wicked.
27.8: For though he has accumulated riches, what is the hope of the godless at the time when God takes away his life?
27.9: For God will not hear his prayer when trouble comes upon him.
27.10: But if he should trust in the Almighty, and always call upon God, God will hear him and answer him.
27.11: But as for you, I will deliver you into the hand of God; so that your works may not be hid from him.
27.12: Behold, all of you have seen it; why then do you boast in vain?
27.13: This is the portion of a wicked man with God, and the heritage of oppressors, which they shall receive from the Almighty.
27.14: If their children are multiplied, it is for the sword; and their offspring shall not be satisfied with bread.
27.15: Those who remain of them shall be buried in death; and their widows shall not weep over them.
27.16: Though they heap up silver like dust and accumulate clothes like clay,
27.17: They may pile them up, yet the righteous shall wear them, and shall also divide their silver.
27.18: For the wicked has built his house upon a spider's web, and like a booth he had made his shelter.
27.19: The rich man shall lie down, but he shall not rise again; he opens his eyes, and he is gone.
27.20: Terrors overtake him like swift water, and like a tempest that rages.
27.21: The east wind shall carry him away in the night, and he is gone; and shall hurl him out of his place.
27.22: For God shall cast him out without pity, and he cannot escape out of his hand.
27.23: He shall smite him with his hand, and shall hiss against him from his dwelling place.

28.1: SURELY there is a mine for silver, and a place where gold is refined.
28.2: Iron is taken out of the earth, and brass is smelted out of the stone.
28.3: God sets an end to darkness, and knows the end of everything, the deep and dark mine and the shadow of death.
28.4: They have inherited a ruined mine from an alien people; they are gone astray from the right path and their number has diminished from among men.
28.5: They lay open the earth, out of which comes sustenance; and from under it is turned up material as if it were burned with fire.
28.6: The stones of it are the place where sapphires are found, and it has dust of gold in its paths.
28.7: There is a path which no bird knows, and the vulture's eye has not seen;
28.8: Wild beasts have not trodden it, nor has the lion passed by it.
28.9: The miner puts forth his hand upon the hard rock to break it; he overturns the mountains from their foundations.
28.10: He divides the rivers by his might; and his eye sees every precious thing.
28.11: He binds up the rivers that they may not overflow; and the thing that is hid, he brings forth to light.
28.12: But where shall wisdom be found? And where is the place of understanding thereof?
28.13: No man knows the treasure thereof; neither is it found except in the land of the living.
28.14: The depth says, It is not in me, and the sea says, It is not with me.
28.15: It cannot be gotten for gold, neither shall silver be counted for its price.
28.16: It cannot be exchanged with the gold of Ophir, with precious onyx or sapphire.
28.17: The gold and the crystal cannot equal it; nor can precious pearls, jewels, and emeralds equal it.
28.18: For the price of wisdom is above that of precious stones. Nor can colored gems, emeralds, and diamonds equal it.
28.19: For the price of wisdom is above everything, and nothing can equal it. The pearls of Ethiopia and the topaz cannot equal it.
28.20: Whence then comes wisdom? And where is the place of understanding?
28.21: It is hid from the eyes of all living, and concealed from the fowls of the air.
28.22: Destruction and death say, We have heard the report of it with our ears.
28.23: Because only God understands the way of it, and he knows the place thereof.
28.24: For he looks to the ends of the earth, and sees under the whole heaven;
28.25: For he made a weight for the wind, and meted it out by the measure.
28.26: He made a decree for the rain, and a way for the lightning and the thunder.
28.27: Then he saw it, and declared it; he measured it, yea, and searched it out.
28.28: And to man he said, Behold, the reverence of God, that is wisdom; and to depart from evil is understanding.

29.1: MOREOVER Job continued his parable, and said,
29.2: O that I were as in months past, as in the days when God took care of me;
29.3: When he put his worship high upon my head, when his lamp shone over me; and when by his light I walked through darkness.
29.4: O, that I were as in the days when I was in favor, when God abode in my tabernacle;
29.5: When the Almighty was yet round about me in my youth;
29.6: When I washed my steps with butter, and the rock poured me out rivers of oil;
29.7: When I went out to the gate of the city and called on the people; and sat down like a poor man in the street,
29.8: The young men saw me and hid themselves; and the aged arose, and respected me.
29.9: The nobles held their peace, and laid their hands on their mouth.
29.10: The voice of the princes was restrained, and their tongues cleaved to the roof of their mouth.
29.11: For when the ear heard me, then it praised me; and when the eye saw me, it gave testimony about me;
29.12: Because I delivered the poor out of distress, and the fatherless who had none to help him.
29.13: The blessing of him who was ready to perish came upon me; and I caused the widow's heart to rejoice.
29.14: I put on righteousness, and it clothed me like a robe and diadem of justice.
29.15: I was eyes to the blind, and feet was I to the lame.
29.16: I was a father to the poor; and the cause which I knew not I searched out.
29.17: And I broke the jaws of the wicked, and snatched the prey out of his teeth.
29.18: Then I said, I shall become straight like a reed, I shall deliver the poor and multiply my days like the sand of the seas.
29.19: My roots are planted by the waters, and the dew lies all night upon my boughs, and at the harvest season I shall be invited to the feast.
29.20: I shall take my bow with me, and renew it in my hand.
29.21: Men listened to me, and waited, and hearkened to my counsel.
29.22: And from my words they departed not, and my speech was pleasing to them.
29.23: They waited for me as for the rain; and they opened their mouths wide as for the spring rain.
29.24: If I ridiculed them, they did not take offense; and they did not turn from the light of my countenance.
29.25: I searched out their ways, and then returned and dwelt as a king in his army, like one who comforts the mourners.

30.1: BUT now they laugh at me, those who are less than I,
30.2: Whose fathers I have disdained, and did not consider them equal to the dogs of my flocks.
30.3: Yea, the strength of their hands, of what use would it have been to me?
30.4: For they had lost their power completely.
30.5: They were forced by bare necessities, like a thief swept off his feet,
30.6: Fleeing to dwell in the cliffs of the valleys, in caves of the earth, in crevices,
30.7: In rocky places, and under bushes.
30.8: The children of fools shall be overthrown together with the children of the wicked; they shall be brought lower than the earth.
30.9: And now I am the subject of their mocking, yea, I have become a byword to them.
30.10: They abhor me, they flee far from me, and do not fail to spit in my face.
30.11: Because they began to deride me and humiliate me, they have also put their bridle in my mouth.
30.12: They rise up against my right hand, they have tripped me up; they have perplexed me through the crookedness of their ways.
30.13: They mar my paths without a cause, they rejoice for what has befallen me; they shall have no helper.
30.14: They shall suffer a great ruin; they shall be broken by the hurricane.
30.15: For they have brought terror upon me; they have pursued my paths like the wind; and my help has passed away like a cloud.
30.16: And now my soul is weary; the days of affliction have taken hold upon me.
30.17: In the night my bones are in pain, and my body has no strength in it.
30.18: I have put on my garment; and girded up myself with my robe.
30.19: But they have cast me into the mire, and I am become like dust and ashes.
30.20: I cry to thee, and thou dost not answer me; I stand up and thou dost not consider me.
30.21: Thou hast treated me as an enemy to thee; with thy strong hand thou hast restrained me.
30.22: Thou liftest me up to the wind; thou causest me to ride upon it, and then thou afflictest me, and makest me wretched.
30.23: And yet I know that thou wilt bring me back from death to the meeting place for all living.
30.24: But he will not stretch out his hand against me, and when I cry to him he will save me.
30.25: I have wept for the poor in the daytime, and my soul was grieved for the fatherless.
30.26: But when I looked for good, evil came; and when I waited for light, there came darkness.
30.27: My heart was agitated, and did not rest; the days of affliction came upon me.
30.28: I walked mournfully without being resentful; I stood up and wept in the congregation.
30.29: I am become a brother to jackals, and a companion to ostriches.
30.30: My skin has shrunk upon me, and my bones are burned as with heat.
30.31: My harp is also turned to mourning, and my song to the voice of those who weep.

31.1: I MADE a vow with my eyes that I would never lust after a virgin.
31.2: For what portion would I have then from God who is above, and what heritage from the Almighty who is on high?
31.3: For it is destruction to the wicked, and punishment to the workers of iniquity.
31.4: He sees my ways, and counts all my steps.
31.5: If I have walked with hypocrites, or if my foot hastened to deceit;
31.6: Let me be weighed in a just balance, that God may know my integrity.
31.7: I have not turned aside my steps from the way, and my heart has not followed after my eyes, and I have acquired nothing unjustly;
31.8: But when I sowed, then I ate, and when I planted, then I cultivated and gathered the crops.
31.9: And if my heart has been enticed by a strange woman, or if I have lain in wait at my neighbor's door;
31.10: Then let my wife grind for another, and let her bake bread at another man's place,
31.11: For this is a heinous crime; yea, such an eye devises a crafty scheme.
31.12: For passion is a fire that consumes to destruction, and it would root out all my increase.
31.13: If I have rejected the cause of my manservant or my maidservant, when he contended with me,
31.14: Without saying, What then shall I do when God rises up in judgment, and when he inquires, what shall I answer him?
31.15: (For, behold, he who made me in the womb made him, and he created us in the same womb);
31.16: If I have withheld the poor from his desire, or have defrauded the widow,
31.17: Or have eaten my bread alone, and the orphans did not eat of it
31.18: (Because from my youth I was brought up in sorrows, and from my mother's womb with sighing);
31.19: If I have seen anyone perishing for want of clothing, or any poor without covering
31.20: (But they were reared upon my knees, and were warmed with the fleece of my sheep);
31.21: If I have lifted up my hand against the fatherless (when I saw him at the door I helped him);
31.22: Then let my arm fall from my shoulder blade, and let it be broken from the bone.
31.23: For the fear of God made me to tremble, and affliction from him came upon me, and because of terror I was unable to rise up.
31.24: If I have made gold my trust, or said about the precious stones, You are my confidence; or have said about fine gold, You are my hope;
31.25: If I have rejoiced because my wealth was great, and because my hand had gotten much;
31.26: If I have adored the sun when it shone, or the moon when in full brightness;
31.27: And if my heart has been secretly enticed, if I have consented to wrongdoings;
31.28: Then God has seen my crafty ways, and I have lied before him.
31.29: If I have rejoiced at the destruction of him who hated me, or exulted myself when misfortune befell him;
31.30: (But I have neither suffered my mouth to sin, nor has my soul wished for any of these things;
31.31: My friends said, Oh this man would give us even of his own flesh! but we are not satisfied,
31.32: And the stranger I did not let lodge in the street, and I opened my door to the guest);
31.33: If I have covered up my sins like some men, or if I have hid my guilt in secret places;
31.34: If I have trampled upon the rights of the others (but on the contrary, it is the multitude of families which has ruined me. Nor have I turned away anyone at the door; or engaged in gossip) let the provocations of God lay me low!
31.35: O that one would hear me! If God is present, let him answer me, and let him write the sentence in a book.
31.36: Surely I would take it upon my shoulder, and make it a crown to me.
31.37: I would declare to him the number of my steps; as a prince I would go near to him.
31.38: Let the earth lament over me, let its furrows weep together,
31.39: If I have eaten its fruits without money; or if I have grieved one whose life is bitter,
31.40: Then let thistles grow instead of wheat and thorns instead of barley. The words of Job are ended.

32.1: SO these three men who wanted to condemn Job ceased answering him, because he was found righteous in their eyes.
32.2: Then Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, was angry; so his wrath against Job kindled, because he justified himself more than God.
32.3: His wrath also kindled against his three friends, because they had found no answer to Job so that they might condemn him.
32.4: Now Elihu had waited to correct Job with words, because the other men were older than he.
32.5: When Elihu saw that these three were unable to answer Job, then he was incensed.
32.6: And Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite answered and said, Because I am younger than you in days and you are old, therefore I was afraid, and did not dare to show you my knowledge.
32.7: For I said, Days should speak, and the multitude of years should teach wisdom.
32.8: Truly, there is a spirit in men; and the breath of the Almighty gives them understanding.
32.9: It is not age that makes men wise; nor do the aged always understand judgment.
32.10: Therefore I say, Hearken to me; I also will show you my knowledge.
32.11: Behold, I kept silent while you spoke; I gave ear until you made an end of speaking, while you searched for words.
32.12: Yea, I understood your testimony, and, behold, there was none of you that could reprove Job, or that could answer his words,
32.13: So that you could not say, We have found wisdom. God has smitten him, not man.
32.14: Now Job has not directed his words against me; neither will I answer him with your speeches.
32.15: They were silent, they answered him no more; their words were all spent, so they held their peace;
32.16: They did not speak; they stood still, and answered him no more.
32.17: I will answer also on my part; I also will show my knowledge.
32.18: For I am full of words; the spirit within me constrains me.
32.19: Behold, I cannot restrain myself, nor can I find relief; I can no longer hold myself from talking.
32.20: I will speak so that I may find relief; I will open my lips and answer.
32.21: I will not be partial toward any person, neither will I be ashamed of the presence of any one.
32.22: For I do not know what shame is; else would my Almighty One soon take me away.

33.1: WHEREFORE, hear my speech, O Job, and hearken to all my sayings.
33.2: Behold, now I have opened my mouth, my tongue speaks in my mouth.
33.3: The words of my mouth are upright, and the utterances of my lips are pure.
33.4: The Spirit of God has stirred me up, and the breath of the Almighty has given me life.
33.5: If you can answer me, then prepare yourself and stand up before me.
33.6: For I am also like you before God; I also am formed out of clay.
33.7: Therefore my admonishings will not make you to tremble, neither will my rebuke be heavy upon you.
33.8: Surely you have spoken in my hearing, and I have heard the voice of your words, saying,
33.9: I am blameless without transgressions, I am righteous; and there is no iniquity in me, and I am far removed from wickedness.
33.10: Behold, he finds occasions against me, he counts me as his enemy.
33.11: He puts my feet in the stocks, he watches all my paths.
33.12: Behold, in this you cannot justify yourself; I will answer you, that God is greater than man.
33.13: Why do you strive with him, seeing that he does not give an account of any of his matters?
33.14: For God speaks once; he does not speak a second time;
33.15: In a dream, in a vision of the night, when deep sleep falls upon men, while slumbering upon the bed;
33.16: Then he opens the ears of men, and humbles them according to their rebelliousness.
33.17: That he may cause man to depart from his evil-doings, and remove pride from him;
33.18: He spares his soul from corruption, and his life from perdition.
33.19: Man is chastened also with pain upon his bed, and the multitude of his bones with strong pain;
33.20: So that his flesh fails because of his fear, and his soul is not satisfied with bread, and covets food.
33.21: His flesh is wasted away because of his fear, so that a greater part of his bones can he seen.
33.22: Yea, his soul draws near to corruption, and his life to death.
33.23: If a man have an angel to whom one would listen once in a thousand times, the angel would show him the way of uprightness
33.24: And be gracious to him and say, Deliver this man lest he go down to corruption; he has found salvation;
33.25: Then his flesh will change to that of his childhood; and he shall return to the days of his youth;
33.26: And he shall pray to God, and he will hear him and be pleased with him, and God shall appear before him with glory; for he will render to men his righteousness.
33.27: Then the uprightness will bear witness concerning the man; and he shall say, I have truly sinned and I am at fault; and it profiteth me not;
33.28: Deliver my soul from perdition, and my life shall see the light.
33.29: Lo, all these things God does three times with a man,
33.30: To bring back his soul from corruption, to see the light of the living.
33.31: Incline your ear, O Job, hearken to me; be silent, and I will speak.
33.32: If you have anything to say, answer me; for I desire that you may be justified.
33.33: But if you will not listen, then be silent, and I shall teach you wisdom.

34.2: Hear my words, O you wise men, and give ear to me, you that have knowledge.
34.3: For the ear tries words, and the palate tastes food.
34.4: Let us choose for us a judge; let him know among ourselves what is good.
34.5: For Job has said, I am righteous; and God has turned aside my judgment.
34.6: Who is the man who has perished without transgression?
34.7: What man is like Job, who drinks up scorning like water?
34.8: Who is a companion and friend of the workers of iniquity, and walks with wicked men?
34.9: For he has said that a man is not justified because he fears God.
34.10: Therefore hearken to me, O you men of understanding; far be it from God that he should do wickedness; and far be it from him that he should commit iniquity.
34.11: For he compensates a man according to his works, and causes every man to be rewarded according to his ways.
34.12: Truly, God does not commit iniquity, neither does God pervert justice.
34.13: Who has control over the earth? Or who has made all the world?
34.14: If he should turn his heart against man, man's spirit and his breath will be gathered to him.
34.15: Then all flesh would perish together, and man would return again to dust.
34.16: If now you have understanding, hear this; hearken to the voice of my words.
34.17: He who hates justice cannot be declared innocent, and he who is innocent will not be condemned justly;
34.18: He who says concerning the king that he is wicked, and yet he is a good ruler over princes and governors;
34.19: And not partial to princes, and does not discriminate against the poor (for they are all the work of his hands);
34.20: In a moment shall he die, and he shall be consumed at midnight, and pass away; he will be rendered powerless by the Almighty.
34.21: For his eyes are upon all the ways of man, and he sees all his goings.
34.22: There is no darkness, nor shadow of death, where the workers of iniquity may hide themselves.
34.23: For he has not set a time for a man that he should enter into judgment with God.
34.24: For he has brought misfortune to many men without number, and sets others in their places.
34.25: Therefore he knows them by their works, and he overturns them in the night.
34.26: Their works shall be crushed under the weight of their wickedness in a land of terror;
34.27: Because they turned aside from following him, and did not consider any of his ways.
34.28: The prayer of the poor comes to him, and he hears the cry of the afflicted.
34.29: When he forgives, who then can condemn? And when he turns his face away, who can forgive the people, or mankind altogether?
34.30: He sees to it that an impious and wicked man shall not reign over the people.
34.31: For God has said, I have forgiven, I will not destroy men who are without sin.
34.32: Inform me now, teach me, if you have committed iniquity;
34.33: I will not answer you any more, because you have sinned, for you have been examined, and not I; therefore speak out what you know.
34.34: Let men of understanding tell me, and let a wise man hearken to me.
34.35: Job has spoken without knowledge, and his words are without understanding.
34.36: Truly, Job has been tested to the end, and yet he is not counted among the wicked.
34.37: And if Job should add to his sins, then his transgression will affect us all, and he still will bring his complaint before God.

35.2: Do you think you were justified in saying, I have been found blameless by God?
35.3: If you have said it, what advantage will it be to you? And what should I gain if I should condemn you?
35.4: I will answer you with words, you and your friends with you.
35.5: Look to the heavens, and observe the clouds which are higher than you.
35.6: If you sin, what difference does it make to him? And if your iniquities be multiplied, what does it matter to him?
35.7: If you are righteous, what do you give to him? Or what does he receive from your hand?
35.8: Your wickedness is to yourself; and your righteousness is to yourself.
35.9: Because of the multitude of oppressions men howl; and many cry out because of iniquity.
35.10: And none says, Where is God my Maker, who gives counsel in the night,
35.11: Who teaches us more than the beasts of the earth, and makes us wiser than the fowls of the air?
35.12: They cry, but he does not answer them,
35.13: Because God does not hear the empty pride of evildoers, nor does he praise it.
35.14: Although you have said, I will not praise him, plead before him and supplicate before him.
35.15: For now he does not punish with his anger; and he does not harm any soul.
35.16: Therefore Job has spoken in vain; he multiplies words without knowledge.

36.2: Bear with me a little, and I will show you; for there are yet words to speak on God's behalf.
36.3: I will fetch my knowledge from afar, and will ascribe righteousness to my Maker.
36.4: For truly my words are not deceitful, and my knowledge is blameless with you.
36.5: Behold, God is mighty, and does not despise him who is pure as milk.
36.6: He does not preserve the life of the wicked; but gives justice to the poor.
36.7: He does not withdraw his eyes from the righteous; he sets kings on the throne; yea, they are exalted for ever.
36.8: And if they be bound in chains, then they go down through destruction to poverty.
36.9: Then he shows them their works, and their transgression because they have exceeded their power.
36.10: He opens also their ears to discipline, and commands that they return from iniquity.
36.11: If they obey and serve him, they will spend their days in prosperity and their years in pleasures.
36.12: But if they do not obey, they shall perish by destruction, and they shall perish without knowledge.
36.13: But the hypocrites in heart shall be consumed, they shall not cry for help; yet they shall cry angrily when he binds them.
36.14: They shall die in youth, and their life is snatched by famine.
36.15: But the meek shall be delivered through his meekness, and he opens their way in time of oppression.
36.16: Even so he shall deliver you from the mouth of the mocker, and give you rest instead of distress; and he shall prepare a table with rich food.
36.17: But he shall judge the wicked to the limit: judgment and justice shall take hold on them.
36.18: He will not threaten you with a raging anger, nor will he cause you to be in need of a great ransom.
36.19: He shall join you, that he may deliver you; you shall not be distressed by any of those who are mighty in power.
36.20: He shall deliver you from those who drive you away in the night, and give peoples for your sake, and the nations for your life.
36.21: Take heed, that you may not return to iniquity: because for this you were tried by poverty.
36.22: Behold, God is mighty in power: who can teach like him?
36.23: Who has enjoined him his way? Or who can say, Thou hast wrought iniquity?
36.24: Remember that his works are great, and all men have praised him.
36.25: All the peoples have seen it, and beheld it from afar.
36.26: Behold, God is great, and we know him not, the number of his years is unsearchable.
36.27: For if we should number the pillars of the heaven, and bind the drops of rain by themselves, which the skies do drop in their season;
36.28: And which the clouds pour down upon men, and cause them to be exceedingly glad;
36.29: Who can understand these things, or the spreading of the clouds out of the greatness of his tabernacle?
36.30: Behold, he spreads his light upon it, and covers the bottom of the sea.
36.31: For by these he judges the people; and he gives food to many.
36.32: He covers the light with the clouds, and then it shines upon them again that they may greet it.
36.33: He shows his possessions to his friends, and to the wicked also.

37.1: AT this also man's heart trembles, and is moved out of its place.
37.2: Listen attentively to the raging of his voice, and the judgment that goes out of his mouth.
37.3: Under the whole of heaven the people shall praise him, and his light shines upon the ends of the earth.
37.4: In his own place, he thunders with the voice of his excellency; and he will not need to search them out when his voice is heard.
37.5: God thunders with his voice; great and marvellous things does he, which we cannot understand.
37.6: For he said to the snow, Fall on the earth; likewise to the gentle rain, and to the heavy rain;
37.7: He limits the power of every man, that all men may know his work.
37.8: Then the wild beasts go into their lurking places, and remain in their dens.
37.9: Out of the inner chambers comes the whirlwind; and cold out of the downpour.
37.10: By the breath of God ice is given; and he causes abundant water to pour down.
37.11: The clouds are stretched out greatly; he spreads the clouds by his light.
37.12: And they turn round about by his counsels, that they may do whatever he commands them upon the face of his habitable earth.
37.13: He causes it to rain, whether it be for the princes or for the land or for kindness to those who are found upon it.
37.14: Hearken to this, O Job: listen and consider the wondrous works of God.
37.15: Do you know what God has ordained for them, and what causes the light of his clouds to shine?
37.16: Do you know the balancing of the clouds, the wondrous works of him who is perfect in knowledge?
37.17: Do you know why your garments get hot when the earth changes its position after the equinox?
37.18: Were you with him when he spread out the great sky, helping him hold it up?
37.19: Teach us what we shall say to him, that we may not hide because of the darkness.
37.20: Relate to him that which he has said; and if a man speaks, surely he shall be consumed.
37.21: And now men cannot see the light which shines in the sky; but the wind passes and cleanses it.
37.22: Golden gleams come out of the north; and light shines from God.
37.23: As for the Almighty, he is excellent in power and in justice; the Prince of the righteous will not afflict his people.
37.24: Therefore men shall fear him, and all that are wise in heart shall tremble before him.

38.1: THEN the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind, and said,
38.2: Who is this that gives counsel by words without knowledge?
38.3: Gird up your loins now, like a valiant man; for I will question you, and you shall answer me.
38.4: Where were you when I laid the foundations of the earth? Declare, if you have understanding.
38.5: Who has laid its measures, if you know? Or who has stretched the line upon it?
38.6: Upon what are its limits resting? Or who laid the cornerstone thereof?
38.7: When did I create the morning stars, and all the angels shouted for joy?
38.8: Or who shut up the sea with gates, when it broke forth as if it had issued out of the womb?
38.9: When I made the cloud the garment of the earth, and thick darkness a swaddling hand for it,
38.10: And prescribed limits for it, and set bars and doors,
38.11: And said, Thus far shall you come, but no farther; and here shall your proud waves be stayed?
38.12: Have you commanded the dawn since your days began; or do you know the place of the morning;
38.13: That it might take hold of the ends of the earth, that the wicked might be thrown out of it?
38.14: So that their bodies shall be turned into clay, and be thrown into a heap.
38.15: The light of sinners shall be withheld, and the arm of the arrogant shall be broken.
38.16: Have you entered into the depths of the sea? Or have you walked in the foundations of the deep?
38.17: Have the gates of death been revealed to you? Or have you seen the gates of the shadow of death?
38.18: Have you seen the whole breadth of the earth? Declare to me if you know it all.
38.19: Where is the dwelling place of light, and where is the place of darkness?
38.20: Do you know its borders and the path to its house?
38.21: Do you remember when you were born, and do you know if you will live many days?
38.22: Have you entered into the chambers of the snow? Or have you seen the storehouses of hail,
38.23: Which are reserved against the time of distress, against the day of battle and war?
38.24: Or in what manner is light distributed, and whence the wind comes forth upon the earth?
38.25: Who causes a flash of lightning and a clap of thunder?
38.26: Who causes it to rain on a land where no man is, in the wilderness where there is no inhabitant,
38.27: To saturate every thicket, and cause the tender grass to spring up?
38.28: Has the rain a father? Or who has begotten the drops of dew?
38.29: Out of whose womb did the dew and ice come forth? And who begot the hoary frost of heaven?
38.30: The waters are hardened like a stone, and the face of the deep is frozen.
38.31: Can you stop the movement of the Pleiades, or have you seen the path of Orion?
38.32: Can you bring forth Mazzaroth in its season? Or can you stand in the paths of Aldebaran?
38.33: Do you know the laws of the heavens? Or do you make ordinances for the earth?
38.34: Can you lift up your voice to the clouds? Or can you cover them with abundance of waters?
38.35: Can you send forth the lightnings, that they may go, and say to you. Here we are?
38.36: Who has put wisdom in the inward parts? Or who has given vision to understanding?
38.37: Who has numbered the clouds by his wisdom? And who has raised the pillars of heaven?
38.38: Who has poured out soil upon the earth, and who has made the steep rocks?
38.39: Who has given prey for the lion? Or filled the appetite of the young lions?
38.40: Who has multiplied the beasts in the field? Or who has provided food for the raven?
38.41: For its young ones cry to God, and faint for lack of food.

39.1: DO you know the time when wild goats bring forth in the steep rocks? Or can you watch the calving of hinds?
39.2: Can you number the months that they fulfill, and know the time when they bring forth?
39.3: And do you know when they kneel and bring forth their young ones?
39.4: They bring up their young ones, until they grow up and are weaned.
39.5: Who has left the wild ass to be free, and made him to escape the yoke?
39.6: For he has made the plain his house, and the salt land his dwelling place.
39.7: He scorns the multitude of cities, and is not afraid of the voice of rulers.
39.8: The tops of mountains are his pasture, and he treads over every green thing.
39.9: Will the unicorn be willing to serve you, or will he spend the night at your crib?
39.10: Can you bind the yoke on the neck of the unicorn? Or will he harrow in a rugged place?
39.11: Will you have confidence in him, because his strength is great? Or will you leave your labor to him?
39.12: Do you trust him, that he will winnow your threshing and gather your grain into the barn?
39.13: The ostrich rouses herself up haughtily; then she comes and makes her nest;
39.14: But she leaves her eggs in the earth to be warmed on the ground.
39.15: And because she has the feet of a bird, forgets that the wild beast may trample them.
39.16: She multiplies her young ones, though they do not stay with her; although her labor is in vain, she has no fear:
39.17: God has increased wisdom, but he has not given her a portion of it.
39.18: She raises herself high like a palm tree; she laughs at the horse and his rider.
39.19: Have you given the horse strength? Have you clothed his neck with armour?
39.20: Can you make him move like the locust? Or can you make him afraid?
39.21: He paws in the plain, and rejoices in the valley; he goes forth armed to the battle.
39.22: He laughs at a pit, and is not frightened; neither does he turn back from the sword.
39.23: The quiver rattles against him, the glittering spear and the lance.
39.24: He gallops with rage that makes the ground to tremble, nor does he fear the sound of the trumpet.
39.25: He makes the sound, Aha, aha; and he smells the battle from afar; he terrifies the officers with his neighing.
39.26: Is it by your wisdom that the hawk was created and wings his way toward the south?
39.27: Does the eagle soar at your command, and make his nest in steep rocks?
39.28: He dwells and lodges on the rock, upon the cliff of the precipice.
39.29: He is sustained by his prey, his eyes behold afar off.
39.30: His young ones suck up blood; and where the slain are, there is he.

40.1: MOREOVER the LORD answered Job, and said,
40.2: Many are the counsels of God; he who reproves God must answer for it.
40.3: Then Job answered the LORD, and said,
40.4: Behold, I am unworthy; what shall I answer thee? I will lay my hand upon my mouth.
40.5: Once I have spoken; but I will not answer; yea, twice, but I will proceed no further.
40.6: Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind, and said,
40.7: Gird up your loins now like a man; I will question you, and you shall declare to me.
40.8: Will you disannul my judgment? Will you even condemn me, that you may be justified?
40.9: Have you an arm like God? Or can you thunder with a voice like him?
40.10: Deck yourself now with majesty and excellency; and array yourself with glory and beauty.
40.11: Cast away the rage of your wrath; and look upon everyone that is proud, and abase him;
40.12: And cast the sinners into their place.
40.13: Bury them in the earth together; cover their faces with fine dust.
40.14: Then will I also give you credit when your own right hand has saved you.
40.15: Behold now the hippopotamus which I made for you; he eats grass like an ox.
40.16: Lo, his strength is in his loins, and his tail stands erect like a cedar tree.
40.17: The sinews of his thighs bulge out.
40.18: His bones are strong as pieces of brass; yea, they are like bars of iron.
40.19: He is the chief among God's creations; for he made him powerful to fight.
40.20: He roams about the mountains, and all the wild beasts of the field lie down under his protection.
40.21: He lurks in the covert of reeds, he couches as a lion.
40.22: The shady trees cover him with their shadow; the willows of the brook encircle him.
40.23: Behold, if he plunges into the river, he is not afraid; he is confident, though the Jordan reaches to his mouth.
40.24: Can one take him with a hook, or catch him with a net? Can one snare him in a trap, or can one bind his tongue with a rope?

41.1: CAN you catch the Leviathan with a hook? Or draw him out with a cord in his mouth?
41.2: Can you put a bridle in his mouth? Or bore his jaw with a thorn?
41.3: Will he make many supplications to you? Or will he speak flattering words to you?
41.4: Will he make a covenant with you? Or will you count him as a servant for ever?
41.5: Will you play with him as with a bird? Or will you keep him as a pet for your children?
41.6: Shall fishermen gather over him? Shall they divide him among many people?
41.7: Can you fill his skin with meat? Or bake his head with fire?
41.8: Try to capture him; such a battle you will have! You will never forget it.
41.9: Behold, Job, you now are set free from your afflictions. So your God will also remove your bitterness.
41.10: One cannot go far off when Leviathan is stirred up; but who then is able to stand before me?
41.11: Who has pre-eminence over me, so that I should surrender?
41.12: Whatever is under the whole heaven is mine.
41.13: I will not keep silence because of his power, and the might of his sinews.
41.14: Who has removed his skin? Who can come near him when the net is lowered?
41.15: Who can open the doors of his mouth? His teeth are terrible round about.
41.16: His mouth is tied up, and closely shut, as with a seal.
41.17: His teeth are so close together that no air can come between them.
41.18: They are joined one to another, they stick together so that they cannot be separated.
41.19: His appearance is full of light, and his eyes are like rays of the dawn.
41.20: Out of his mouth go burning lamps, and sparks of fire leap out.
41.21: Out of his nostrils goes smoke, like a flame spreading round the sides of a pot.
41.22: His breath kindles coals, and a flame goes out of his mouth.
41.23: He has great strength in his neck, and fear is to him like dancing.
41.24: His meat is good and fat, and it is nourishing.
41.25: His heart is never made to quake for fear, but is firm like a stone; yea as hard as flint.
41.26: Because of the fear of him, the mighty are afraid;
41.28: The wound of the sword is of no effect; the lances of the mighty he removes.
41.29: He considers iron like straw, and brass like rotten wood.
41.30: The bow cannot make him flee; he treats slingstones as stubble.
41.31: He laughs at the spear; he is at home in the deep as if he were on the dry land.
41.32: With his strong body he walks upon the ground.
41.33: He brings to destruction whatever is proud.
41.34: He is a king over all things in the deep.

42.1: THEN Job answered the LORD, and said,
42.2: I know that thou canst do all these things, and that no purpose can be hid from thee.
42.3: Who am I to think that I can give counsel without knowledge? Therefore thou hast declared to me that I have uttered that which I did not understand, things too wonderful for me which I did not know.
42.4: Hear me, I pray thee, and I will speak; I will ask thee, and declare thou to me;
42.5: I have heard of thee by the hearing of the ear, but now my eye sees thee.
42.6: Therefore, I will keep silent, and repent in dust and ashes.
42.7: And it came to pass, after the LORD had spoken these words to Job, the LORD said to Eliphaz the Temanite, My wrath is kindled against you, and against your two friends; for you have not spoken in my presence that which is right, as my servant Job has.
42.8: Now therefore take for yourselves seven bullocks and seven rams, and go to my servant Job, and offer up for yourselves a burnt offering; and my servant Job shall pray for you; for him will I accept, lest I deal contemptuously with you, for you have not spoken in my presence the thing which is right, as my servant Job has done.
42.9: So Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite went, and did according as the Lord had told them; and the LORD favored Job.
42.10: And the LORD restored to Job all that he had lost, when he prayed for his friends; also the LORD gave Job twice as much as he had before.
42.11: Then came there to him all his brothers and all his sisters and all they that had been of his acquaintance before, and did eat bread with him in his house; for they had been in distress over him, and they comforted him for all the hardships that the LORD had brought upon him; and every man also gave him a ewe, and every one an earring of gold.
42.12: So the LORD blessed the latter end of Job more than his beginning; for he had fourteen thousand sheep and six thousand camels and a thousand yoke of oxen and a thousand she-asses.
42.13: He also had seven sons and three daughters.
42.14: And he named the first Jemima; and the name of the second was Kezia; and the name of the third, Karna-puch.
42.15: And in all the land were found no women as beautiful as the daughters of Job; and their father gave them an inheritance among their brothers.
42.16: After this Job lived one hundred and forty years, and saw his sons and his son's sons, even four generations.
42.17: So Job died, being old and contented and full of days.

1.1: BLESSED is the man who walks not in the way of the ungodly, nor abides by the counsel of sinners, nor sits in the company of mockers;
1.2: But his delight is in the law of the LORD, and on his law does he meditate day and night.
1.3: And he shall be like a tree planted by a stream of water, that brings forth its fruit in its season, whose leaves fall not off; and whatsoever he begins he accomplishes.
1.4: The ungodly are not so, but are like the chaff which the wind drives away.
1.5: Therefore the ungodly shall not be justified in the judgment, nor sinners in the congregation of the righteous;
1.6: For the LORD knows the way of the righteous; but the way of the ungodly shall perish.

2.1: WHY do the Gentiles rage and the peoples imagine vain things?
2.2: The kings of the earth and the rulers have conspired and have taken counsel together against the LORD and against his anointed, saying,
2.3: Let us break their bands asunder, and let us cast away their yoke from us.
2.4: He that dwells in heaven shall laugh, and the LORD shall mock at them.
2.5: Then shall he speak to them in his anger, and terrify them in his wrath and say,
2.6: I have appointed my king over Zion, my holy mountain,
2.7: To declare my promise; the LORD has said to me, You are my Son; this day have I begotten you.
2.8: Ask of me, and I shall give you the heathen for your inheritance and the uttermost parts of the earth for your dominion.
2.9: You shall shepherd them with a rod of iron; you shall break them in pieces like a potter's vessel.
2.10: Be wise now, therefore, O kings; be instructed, O judges of the earth.
2.11: Serve the LORD with reverence, and uphold him with trembling.
2.12: Kiss the Son, lest he be angry, and you perish from his way while his wrath is kindled but a little. Blessed are all they that put their trust in him.

3.1: O LORD, how my oppressors are increased! Many are they that rise up against me.
3.2: Many there are that say to my soul, You have no salvation in your God.
3.3: But thou, O LORD, art my help and my glory, and the lifter up of my head.
3.4: I have cried to the LORD with my voice, and he has answered me from his holy mountain.
3.5: I lay down and slept; and I awoke; for the LORD sustained me.
3.6: I will not be afraid of thousands of people that have surrounded me and set themselves against me.
3.7: Arise, O LORD my God, and save me; for thou hast smitten all my enemies upon their cheeks; thou hast broken the teeth of the ungodly.
3.8: For salvation belongs to the LORD; and thy blessing is upon thy people.

4.1: WHEN I have called thee, thou hast answered me, O my God and Saviour of my righteousness; thou hast comforted me when I was in distress; have mercy upon me and hear my prayer.
4.2: Men, how long will you obscure my glory? how long will you love vanity? do you want deception forever?
4.3: But know that the LORD has set apart for himself him that is wonderful; the LORD will hear when I call to him.
4.4: Be angry and yet sin not; commune with your own heart and meditate upon your bed.
4.5: Offer the sacrifices of righteousness and put your trust in the LORD.
4.6: There are many that say, Who can show us a good man so that he may shine upon us the light of his countenance?
4.7: O LORD, thou hast put gladness in my heart more than in the time that their wheat and their wine and their oil increased.
4.8: in peace I will both lie down and sleep; for thou, O LORD, alone makest me dwell in safety.

5.1: GIVE ear to my words, O LORD, and consider my meditation.
5.2: Hearken to the voice of my cry, my King and my God; for to thee do I pray.
5.3: My voice shalt thou hear in the morning, O LORD: and in the morning will I prepare myself and see thee.
5.4: For thou art not a God that hath pleasure in wickedness; neither shall evil dwell with thee.
5.5: The proud shall not stand in thy sight; thou hatest all workers of iniquity.
5.6: Thou shalt destroy them that speak falsehood; the LORD will reject the bloody and deceitful man.
5.7: But as for me, I will come into thy house in the multitude of thy mercy; and I will enter into thy house and worship in thy holy temple.
5.8: Lead me, O LORD, in thy reverence and righteousness; and because of mine enemies, make thy way straight before my face.
5.9: For there is no justice in their mouth; there is wickedness in them; their throat is an open sepulchre; they deceive with their tongues.
5.10: Condemn thou them, O God; let them fall by their own counsels; cast them out in the multitude of their wickedness, for they have provoked thee.
5.11: But let all those that put their trust in thee rejoice; they shall glorify thee forever, and thou shalt dwell among them; and all they that love thy name shall be strengthened by thee.
5.12: For thou wilt bless the righteous; O LORD, thou hast adorned me like a perfect shield.

6.1: O LORD, rebuke me not in thine anger, neither chasten me in thy hot displeasure.
6.2: Have mercy upon me, O LORD; for I am weak; O LORD, heal me; for my bones are troubled.
6.3: My soul is also troubled exceedingly but thou, O LORD, how long?
6.4: Return, O LORD, and deliver my soul: save me for thy mercies' sake.
6.5: For in death there is no remembrance of thee; in Sheol who shall give thee thanks?
6.6: I am weary with my groaning; and every night I water my bed and wash my mattress with my tears.
6.7: Mine eye is weakened because of anger; and I am troubled by all my enemies.
6.8: Depart from me, all you workers of iniquity; for the LORD has heard the voice of my weeping.
6.9: The LORD has heard my supplication; the LORD has received my prayer.
6.10: Let all my enemies be ashamed and defeated; let them turn back and be destroyed suddenly.

7.1: O LORD my God, in thee do I put my trust; save me; from all them that persecute me, deliver me,
7.2: Lest my soul be torn as by a lion, and there is no one to save me and to deliver me.
7.3: O LORD my God, if I have done this thing and if there be iniquity in my hands,
7.4: If I have been vengeful to him that has done me evil, and if I have oppressed my enemies without a cause;
7.5: Let the enemy pursue me and overtake me, yea, let him tread down my life upon the earth and lay my honor in the dust.
7.6: Arise, O LORD, in thine anger, lift up thyself over the neck of mine enemies; and make me alert in the judgment that thou hast commanded.
7.7: Let the congregation of the peoples circle thee about; and for their sakes therefore return thou on high.
7.8: The LORD shall judge the people; judge me, O LORD, according to my righteousness and according to the integrity that is in me.
7.9: Oh let the evil of the wicked come to an end; and establish thou the righteous, O thou searcher of hearts and souls.
7.10: O God who saveth the upright in heart, O righteous God, help me.
7.11: God is a righteous judge; yea he is not angry every day.
7.12: If he turn not from his anger, he will whet his sword and bend his bow and make it ready.
7.13: He has also prepared for himself the instruments of wrath; he pointed his arrows against the persecutor.
7.14: Because the wicked has become corrupt and has conceived mischief and brought forth falsehood,
7.15: He has made a well, and deepened it, and is fallen into the pit which he made.
7.16: His mischief shall return upon his own head, and his iniquity upon his own pate.
7.17: I will praise the LORD according to my righteousness; and I will sing praise to the name of the LORD most high.

8.1: O LORD, our LORD, how excellent is thy name in all the earth! Thou hast set thy glory upon the heavens.
8.2: Out of the mouth of young men and infants hast thou established thy glory because of thine enemies, that thou mightest destroy the enemy and the avenger.
8.3: For thy heavens have seen the work of thy fingers, the moon and the stars, which thou hast ordained;
8.4: What is man, that thou art mindful of him? and the son of man, that thou visitest him?
8.5: For thou hast made him a little lower than the angels, and hast clothed him with glory and honor.
8.6: Thou madest him to have dominion over the works of thy hands; thou hast put all things under his feet,
8.7: All sheep and oxen, yea, and the beasts of the wilderness;
8.8: The fowl of the air and the fish of the sea which pass through the paths of the seas.
8.9: O LORD, our LORD, how excellent is thy name in all the earth!

9.1: I WILL praise thee, O LORD, with my whole heart; I will show forth all thy marvelous works.
9.2: I will be glad and rejoice in thee and I will sing praise to thy name, O thou most High.
9.3: When mine enemies are beaten back, they shall stumble and perish before thy presence.
9.4: For thou hast maintained my right and my cause; thou hast sat on the throne, O thou righteous judge.
9.5: Thou hast rebuked the Gentiles and thou hast destroyed the wicked; thou hast blotted out their name for ever and ever.
9.6: My enemies have been annihilated by the sword for ever; and thou hast destroyed the villages and their very memory hath perished.
9.7: But the LORD shall endure for ever; he has prepared his throne for judgment.
9.8: And he shall judge the world in righteousness and the people in uprightness.
9.9: The LORD also will be a refuge for the poor, a refuge in times of trouble.
9.10: And they that know thy name will put their trust in thee; for thou hast not forsaken them that seek thee, O LORD.
9.11: Sing praises to the LORD, who dwells in Zion; declare among the people his skillful doings;
9.12: For he has remembered to avenge their blood; he forgets not the cry of the poor.
9.13: Have mercy upon me, O LORD, and consider my trouble which I suffer of them that hate me, O thou that removest me away from the gates of death,
9.14: That I may declare all thy praise in the gates of the daughter of Zion; I will rejoice in thy salvation.
9.15: The Gentiles are sunk down in the pit that they made; and their foot is caught in the net which they hid.
9.16: The LORD makes known the judgment which he executes; the wicked is snared in the work of his own hands.
9.17: The wicked shall be turned into Sheol, and all the peoples that forsake God.
9.18: For the poor shall not always be forgotten; and the hope of the poor shall not perish forever.
9.19: Arise, O LORD; let not man prevail; let the Gentiles be judged in thy sight.
9.20: Appoint for them a lawgiver, that the Gentiles may know themselves to be but men.

10.1: WHY standest thou afar off, O LORD? and witholdest thy care in times of trouble?
10.2: The pride of the wicked maketh the poor to suffer; let them be taken in the devices that they have conceived.
10.3: For the ungodly boasts of his own desire, and the LORD is angry when the wicked is blessed.
10.4: The wicked in the pride of his countenance will not seek after God; and there is no God in all his thoughts.
10.5: His ways are always weak; thy judgments are far above out of his sight; as for all his enemies, he despises them.
10.6: He says in his heart, I shall not be moved from generation to generation; for he conceives evil.
10.7: His mouth is full of cursing and deceit and fraud; under his tongue is mischief and deceit.
10.8: He sits in the lurking place of a den; and in a secret place does he murder the innocent; his eyes spy on the destitute.
10.9: He lies in wait to snare the poor by drawing him into his net.
