26.23: And he answered and said, He who dips his hand with me in the dish, he will betray me.
26.24: The Son of man is going through, just as it is written concerning him; but woe to the man by whose hand the Son of man is betrayed! it would have been far better for that man never to have been born.
26.25: Then Judas the traitor answered and said, Master, perhaps it is I? Jesus said to him, You say that.
26.26: While they were eating, Jesus took bread and blessed it, and he broke it, and gave it to his disciples, and he said, Take, eat; this is my body.
26.27: Then he took the cup and gave thanks, and gave it to them and said, Take, drink of it, all of you.
26.28: This is my blood of the new covenant which is shed for many for the remission of sins.
26.29: But I say to you, from now on I shall not drink from this fruit of the vine, until the day when I drink it anew with you in the kingdom of God.
26.30: And they offered praise, and went out to the Mount of Olives.
26.31: Then Jesus said to them, All of you will deny me this night; for it is written, I will smite the shepherd, and the sheep of his flock will be scattered.
26.32: But after I am risen, I will be in Galilee before you.
26.33: Peter answered and said to him, Even if every man should deny you, I will never deny you.
26.34: Jesus said to him, Truly I say to you, that in this very night, before the cock crows, you will deny me three times.
26.35: Peter said to him, Even if I must die with you, I will never deny you. All the disciples said likewise.
26.36: Then Jesus came with them to a place which is called Gethsemane, and he said to his disciples, Sit down here, while I go to pray.
26.37: And he took Peter and the two sons of Zebedee, and he began to be sorrowful and oppressed.
26.38: He said to them, My soul is sorrowful even to death; wait for me here, and watch with me.
26.39: And he went a little further and fell on his face, and prayed saying, O my Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from me; but let it be, not as I will, but as you.
26.40: Then he came to his disciples and found them sleeping, and he said to Peter, So, you were not able to watch with me even for one hour?
26.41: Awake and pray, that you may not enter into temptation; the spirit indeed is ready, but the body is weak.
26.42: He went away again the second time and prayed and said, O my Father, if this cup cannot pass, and if I have to drink it, let it be according to your will.
26.43: He came again and found them sleeping, for their eyes were heavy.
26.44: And he left them and went away again and prayed the third time, and he said the same word.
26.45: Then he came to his disciples and said to them, Sleep from now on and get your rest; behold, the hour has come, and the Son of man will be delivered into the hands of sinners.
26.46: Arise, let us go; behold, he who is to deliver me has arrived.
26.47: While he was speaking, behold, Judas the traitor, one of the twelve, came and with him a large crowd with swords and staves, from the high priests and the elders of the people.
26.48: Now Judas the traitor had given them a sign, saying, He whom I kiss, it is he, arrest him.
26.49: And immediately he came up to Jesus and said, Peace, Master; and he kissed him.
26.50: Jesus said to him, Is it for this that you have come, my friend? Then they came near and laid hands on Jesus, and arrested him.
26.51: And behold, one of those who were with Jesus stretched out his hand and drew a sword, and struck it at the servant of the high priest, and cut off his ear.
26.52: Then Jesus said to him, Return the sword to its place; for all who take swords will die by swords.
26.53: Or do you think that I cannot ask of my Father, and he will now raise up for me more than twelve legions of angels?
26.54: How then could the scriptures be fulfilled, that it must be so?
26.55: At that very hour Jesus said to the people, Have you come out with swords and staves to arrest me like a bandit? I sat with you every day, teaching in the temple, and you did not arrest me.
26.56: But this has happened so that the scriptures of the prophets might be fulfilled. Then all the disciples left him, and fled.
26.57: And those who had arrested Jesus took him to Caiaphas the high priest, where the scribes and the elders had assembled.
26.58: But Simon Peter followed him afar off, up to the courtyard of the high priest, and he went inside and sat with the soldiers, to see the end.
26.59: Now the high priests and the elders and the whole council were seeking witnesses against Jesus, so that they might put him to death.
26.60: But they could not find any; then there came a great many false witnesses; but at the end two came forward,
26.61: And said, This man said, I can tear down the temple of God, and build it in three days.
26.62: And the high priest stood up and said to him, You are not answering anything. What is it that these men testify against you?
26.63: But Jesus was silent. Then the high priest answered and said to him, I adjure you by the living God, to tell us if you are the Christ, the Son of God?
26.64: Jesus said to him, You say that. But I say to you that from henceforth you will see the Son of man sitting at the right hand of the power, and coming upon the clouds of the sky.
26.65: The high priest then rent his clothes and said, Behold, he is blaspheming; why therefore do we need witnesses? behold, you have now heard his blasphemy.
26.66: What else do you want? They answered and said, He is guilty of death.
26.67: Then they spat in his face, and struck him on his head, and others beat him,
26.68: Saying, O Christ, prophesy to us; who smote you?
26.69: Now Peter sat outside in the courtyard; and a maidservant came up to him, and said to him, You also were with Jesus the Nazarene.
26.70: But he denied it before all of them, and said, I do not understand what you are saying.
26.71: And as he was going to the porch, another one saw him, and she said to them, This man was also there with Jesus the Nazarene.
26.72: Again he denied it with oaths, I do not know the man.
26.73: After a while, those who were standing came up, and said to Peter, Truly you also are one of them, for even your speech proves it.
26.74: Then he began to curse and to swear, I do not know the man. At that very hour the cock crowed.
26.75: And Peter remembered the word of Jesus, which he had said to him, Before the cock crows, you will deny me three times. And he went outside and wept bitterly.

27.1: WHEN it was morning, the high priests and the elders of the people took counsel concerning Jesus, how to put him to death.
27.2: So they bound him, and took him and delivered him to Pilate the governor.
27.3: Then Judas the traitor, when he saw that Jesus was convicted, repented, and went away and brought back the same thirty pieces of silver to the high priests and the elders.
27.4: And he said, I have sinned, because I have betrayed innocent blood. But they said to him, What is that to us? You know better.
27.5: Then he threw the silver in the temple, and departed; and he went and hanged himself.
27.6: The high priests took the silver and said, It is not lawful to put it in the house of offerings, because it is the price of blood.
27.7: And they took counsel, and bought with it the potters field, for a cemetery for strangers.
27.8: On this account that field was called The field of blood, to this day.
27.9: Then what was spoken by the prophet was fulfilled, who said, I took the thirty pieces of silver, the costly price which was bargained with the children of Israel.
27.10: And I gave them for the potters field, as the Lord commanded me.
27.11: And Jesus stood before the governor; and the governor asked him and said to him, Are you the King of the Jews? Jesus said to him, You say that.
27.12: And while the chief priests and elders were accusing him, he gave no answer.
27.13: Then Pilate said to him, Do you not hear how much they testify against you?
27.14: But he did not answer him, not even a word; and because of this Pilate marvelled greatly.
27.15: Now on every feast day it was the custom of the governor to release one prisoner to the people, anyone whom they wanted.
27.16: They had a well-known prisoner, called Bar-Abbas, who was bound.
27.17: When they were gathered together, Pilate said to them, Whom do you want me to release to you? Bar-Abbas, or Jesus who is called the Christ?
27.18: For Pilate knew that because of envy they had delivered him.
27.19: When the governor was sitting on his judgment seat, his wife sent to him and said to him, Have nothing to do with that righteous man; for today I have suffered a great deal in my dream because of him.
27.20: But the high priests and the elders urged the people to ask for Bar-Abbas, and to destroy Jesus.
27.21: And the governor answered and said to them, Which of these two do you want me to release to you? They said, Bar-Abbas.
27.22: Pilate said to them, What shall I then do with Jesus who is called the Christ? They all said, Let him be crucified.
27.23: Pilate said to them, What evil has he done? But they cried out the more and said, Let him be crucified.
27.24: Now when Pilate saw that he was gaining nothing, but that instead confusion was increasing, he took water and washed his hands before the people, and said, I am innocent of the blood of this righteous man; do as you please.
27.25: All the people then answered and said, Let his blood be on us and on our children.
27.26: Then he released to them Bar-Abbas, and had Jesus scourged with whips, and delivered to be crucified.
27.27: Then the soldiers of the governor took Jesus into the Praetorium, and the whole company gathered around him.
27.28: And they removed his clothes and put on him a scarlet robe.
27.29: And they wove a crown of thorns and put it on his head, and a reed in his right hand; and they knelt on their knees before him, and they were mocking him and saying, Hail, King of the Jews!
27.30: And they spat in his face, and took the reed and struck him on his head.
27.31: And when they had mocked him, they took off the robe from him and put on him his own clothes, and took him away to be crucified.
27.32: And as they were going out, they found a man of Cyrene, whose name was Simon, whom they compelled to carry his cross.
27.33: And they came to a place which is called Golgotha, which is interpreted The Skull.
27.34: And they gave him to drink vinegar mixed with gall; and he tasted it, but he would not drink.
27.35: And when they had crucified him, they divided his clothes by casting lots.
27.36: And they were sitting there and watching him.
27.37: And they placed above his head in writing the reason for his death: THIS IS JESUS THE KING OF THE JEWS.
27.38: And there were crucified with him two bandits, one on his right and one on his left.
27.39: And those who passed by blasphemed against him, nodding their heads,
27.40: And saying, O you who can tear down the temple and build it in three days, deliver yourself, if you are the Son of God, and come down from the cross.
27.41: The high priests likewise were mocking, together with the scribes, the elders and the Pharisees.
27.42: And they were saying, He saved others, but he cannot save himself. If he is the King of Israel, let him now come down from the cross, so that we may see and believe in him.
27.43: He trusted in God; let him save him now, if he is pleased with him; for he said, I am Gods Son.
27.44: The bandits also, who were crucified with him were reproaching him.
27.45: Now from the sixth hour, there was darkness over all the land, until the ninth hour.
27.46: And about the ninth hour, Jesus cried out with a loud voice and said, Eli, Eli, lmana shabachthani! which means, My God, my God, for this I was kept!
27.47: Some of the men who were standing by, when they heard it, said, This man has called for Elijah.
27.48: And immediately one of them ran and took a sponge and filled it with vinegar, and put it on a reed, and gave him to drink.
27.49: But the rest said, Hush, let us see if Elijah will come to save him.
27.50: But Jesus again cried out with a loud voice, and gave up his breath.
27.51: And immediately the door curtains of the temple were rent in two, from the top to the bottom; and the earth quaked, and the rocks split;
27.52: And the tombs were opened; and the bodies of a great many saints who were sleeping in death rose up,
27.53: And they went out; and after his resurrection, they entered into the holy city, and appeared to a great many.
27.54: When the centurion and those who were with him watching Jesus, saw the earthquake and all that happened, they were very much frightened, and they said, Truly this man was the Son of God.
27.55: There were also many women there, who were looking from afar, those who had followed Jesus from Galilee, and who used to minister to him.
27.56: One of them was Mary of Magdala; and Mary the mother of James and Joses, and the mother of the sons of Zebedee.
27.57: When evening came, there came a rich man of Arimathaea, whose name was Joseph, who was also a disciple of Jesus.
27.58: He went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus. And Pilate commanded that the body should be given to him.
27.59: So Joseph took the body, and wrapped it in a shroud of fine linen,
27.60: And laid it in his own new tomb which was hewn in a rock; and they rolled a large stone, and placed it against the door of the tomb, and went away.
27.61: And there were there Mary of Magdala and the other Mary, who were sitting opposite the tomb.
27.62: The next day, which is after Friday, the high priests and the Pharisees together came to Pilate,
27.63: And they said to him, Our lord, we have just remembered that that deceiver used to say when he was alive, After three days I will rise again.
27.64: Now, therefore, command that precautions be taken at the tomb for three days. It is probable that his disciples may come and steal him at night, and then say to the people, He has risen from the dead; and the last deception will be worse than the first.
27.65: Pilate said to them, You have guards; go and take precautions as best you know.
27.66: So they went and kept a watch at the tomb, and together with the guards they sealed the stone.

28.1: IN the evening of the sabbath day, when the first day of the week began, there came Mary of Magdala and the other Mary, to see the tomb.
28.2: And behold, a great earthquake took place; for the angel of the Lord came down from heaven, and went up and rolled away the stone from the door, and sat on it.
28.3: His appearance was like lightning, and his garments white as snow.
28.4: And for fear of him the guards who were watching trembled, and became as if they were dead.
28.5: But the angel answered and said to the women, You need not be afraid; for I know that you are seeking Jesus who was crucified.
28.6: He is not here, for he has risen, just as he had said. Come in, see the place where our Lord was laid.
28.7: And go quickly, and tell his disciples that he has risen from the dead; and behold, he will be before you to Galilee; there you will see him; behold, I have told you.
28.8: And they went away hurriedly from the tomb with fear and with great joy, running to tell his disciples.
28.9: And behold, Jesus met them, and said to them, Peace be to you. And they came up and laid hold of his feet, and worshipped him.
28.10: Then Jesus said to them, Do not be afraid; but go and tell my brethren to go to Galilee, and there they shall see me.
28.11: When they were going, some of the guards came into the city, and told the high priests everything that had happened.
28.12: So they gathered with the elders and took counsel; and they gave money, not a small sum, to the guards,
28.13: Telling them, Say that his disciples came by night and stole him while we were sleeping.
28.14: And if this should be heard by the governor, we will appeal to him, and declare that you are blameless.
28.15: So they took the money, and did as they were instructed; and this word went out among the Jews, until this day.
28.16: The eleven disciples then went to Galilee to a mountain, where Jesus had promised to meet them.
28.17: And when they saw him, they worshipped him; but some of them were doubtful.
28.18: And Jesus came up and spoke with them, and said to them, All power in heaven and on earth has been given to me. Just as my Father has sent me I am also sending you.
28.19: Go, therefore, and convert all nations; and baptize them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit;
28.20: And teach them to obey everything that I have commanded you; and, behold, I am with you all the days, to the end of the world. Amen.

1.1: THE beginning of the gospel of Jesus Christ, the Son of God.
1.2: As it is written in Isaiah the prophet, Behold I send my messenger before your face, that he may prepare your way,
1.3: The voice that cries in the wilderness, Make ready the way of the Lord, and straighten his high ways.
1.4: John was in the wilderness, baptizing and preaching the baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins,
1.5: And the whole province of Judaea went out to him, and all the people of Jerusalem; and he baptized them in the river Jordan, when they confessed their sins.
1.6: John wore a dress of camels hair, with a girdle of leather fastened around his loins; and his food was locusts and wild honey.
1.7: And he preached saying, Behold, there is coming after me one who is mightier than myself, even the strings of whose shoes I am not good enough to bend down and untie.
1.8: I have baptized you with water; but he will baptize you with the Holy Spirit.
1.9: And it came to pass in those days, Jesus came from Nazareth of Galilee, and was baptized in the Jordan by John.
1.10: And immediately, as he went up out of the water, he saw the sky was clear open, and the Spirit as a dove came down upon him.
1.11: And a voice came from heaven, You are my beloved Son, I am pleased with you.
1.12: And immediately the Spirit drove him out into the wilderness.
1.13: And he was there in the wilderness forty days, being tried out by Satan; and he was with the wild beasts; and the angels ministered to him.
1.14: But after John was delivered up, Jesus came to Galilee, preaching the gospel of the kingdom of God,
1.15: And saying, The time has come to an end, and the kingdom of God is at hand; repent and believe in the gospel.
1.16: While he walked along the sea of Galilee, he saw Simon and Andrew his brother throwing their nets into the sea; for they were fishermen.
1.17: And Jesus said to them, Come after me, and I will make you fishers of men.
1.18: And straightway they left their nets, and went after him.
1.19: And when he went a little further, he saw James the son of Zebedee and his brother John; they also were in a boat mending their nets.
1.20: And he called them; and immediately they left their father Zebedee with the hired men, and went after him.
1.21: When they entered into Capernaum, straightway he taught on the sabbaths in their synagogues.
1.22: And they were amazed at his teaching; for he taught them as one with an authority, and not like their scribes.
1.23: And there was in their synagogue a man who had in him an unclean spirit; and he cried out,
1.24: And said, Jesus of Nazareth, what have we in common? Have you come to destroy us? I know you, who you are, Holy One of God.
1.25: And Jesus rebuked him and said, Be silent, and come out of him.
1.26: And the unclean spirit threw him down, and cried out in a loud voice, and left him.
1.27: And they were all astonished, and kept asking one another saying, What does this mean? and what is this new teaching, that with such a power he commands even unclean spirits and they obey him?
1.28: And his fame immediately spread throughout the country of Galilee.
1.29: Then they went out of the synagogue, and came to the house of Simon and Andrew, together with James and John.
1.30: And Simons mother-in-law was laid up with fever; and they spoke to him about her.
1.31: And he went and held her hand, and lifted her up; and immediately the fever left her, and she ministered to them.
1.32: In the evening towards sunset, they brought to him all who were seriously sick, and the insane.
1.33: And the whole city was gathered at the door.
1.34: And he healed many who were seriously sick with divers diseases, and he restored many who were insane; and he did not allow the insane to speak because some of them were his acquaintances.
1.35: And in the morning he rose up very early and went away to a lonely place, and there prayed.
1.36: And Simon and those who were with him were looking for him.
1.37: And when they found him, they said to him, Everyone wants you.
1.38: He said to them, Let us walk to the neighboring towns and cities, so that I may preach there also; because I came for this.
1.39: And he preached in all their synagogues throughout Galilee, and cast out demons.
1.40: And there came to him a leper, who fell down at his feet, and begged him, saying, If you will, you can make me clean.
1.41: And Jesus had mercy on him, and stretched out his hand and touched him, and said, I am willing; be clean.
1.42: And in that hour his leprosy disappeared from him, and he became clean.
1.43: And Jesus rebuked him and put him out,
1.44: And said to him, Look here, why are you telling it to the people? but go away, show yourself to the priests, and offer an offering for the sake of your cleansing, according to what Moses commanded, as their testimonial.
1.45: But when he went out, he began to publish it still more, and to spread the word, so that Jesus was no longer able to enter the city openly, but he remained outside in a lonely place; and yet they came to him from every place.

2.1: AND Jesus entered again into Capernaum for a few days; and when they heard that he was in a house,
2.2: A great many gathered together so that it was impossible to hold them, not even in front of the entrance; so he spoke a few words to them.
2.3: And they came to him, and brought to him a paralyzed man, carried between four men.
2.4: But as they were unable to come near him because of the crowd, they went up to the roof and uncovered it over the place where Jesus was; and they lowered the quilt-bed in which the paralyzed man lay.
2.5: When Jesus saw their faith, he said to the paralytic, My son, your sins are forgiven.
2.6: Now some of the scribes and Pharisees were sitting there, and they reasoned in their hearts,
2.7: Why does this man speak blasphemy? Who can forgive sins except God only?
2.8: But Jesus perceived in his spirit that they were reasoning among themselves, and he said to them, Why do you reason these things in your heart?
2.9: Which is the easier, to say to the paralytic, Your sins are forgiven; or to say, Rise, take up your quilt-bed and walk?
2.10: But that you may know that the Son of man has power on earth to forgive sins, he said to the paralytic,
2.11: I tell you, Rise, take up your quilt-bed, and go to your house.
2.12: And immediately he rose, and took up his quilt-bed and went out before the eyes of them all; and they were all amazed, and gave glory to God, saying, We have never seen anything like it.
2.13: And he went out again by the seaside, and all the people kept coming to him, and he taught them.
2.14: And as he passed by, he saw Levi the son of Alphaeus, sitting at the custom house, and he said to him, Follow me; and he got up and followed him.
2.15: And it happened that while he was a guest at his house, a great many publicans and sinners were also guests with Jesus and his disciples; for there were many, and they followed him.
2.16: And when the scribes and the Pharisees saw him eating with the publicans and sinners, they said to his disciples, Why does he eat and drink with publicans and sinners?
2.17: When Jesus heard it, he said to them, Those who are healthy need no doctor, but those who are seriously sick; I came not to call the righteous, but the sinners.
2.18: The disciples of John and of the Pharisees were fasting; and they came and said to him, Why do the disciples of John and of the Pharisees fast, and your own disciples do not fast?
2.19: Jesus said to them, Why, can the sons of the wedding feast fast as long as the bridegroom is with them? No!
2.20: But the days will come when the bridegroom is taken away from them, then in that day they will fast.
2.21: No man puts a new patch and sews it on a worn out garment, so that the new patch may not weaken the old, and the hole become larger.
2.22: And no man pours new wine into old wine-skins, so that the wine may not rend the skins and the skins be ruined, and the wine run out; but they pour new wine into new wine-skins.
2.23: And it happened that while Jesus was going through the wheat fields on the sabbath, his disciples walked and pulled up the ears of wheat.
2.24: And the Pharisees said to him, Look what they are doing on the sabbath! that which is unlawful.
2.25: Jesus said to them, Have you not read what David did, when he was in need and hungry, he and those who were with him?
2.26: How he entered into the house of God when Abiathar was the chief priest, and ate the bread which was on the table of the Lord, which was not lawful to be eaten except by the priests, and he gave it also to those who were with him?
2.27: And he said to them, The sabbath was created for the sake of man, and not man for the sake of the sabbath.
2.28: The Son of man therefore is the Lord also of the sabbath.

3.1: JESUS entered again into the synagogue, and there was there a man whose hand was withered.
3.2: And they watched him if he would heal him on the sabbath, that they might accuse him.
3.3: And he said to the man whose hand was withered, Stand up in the midst.
3.4: Then he said to them also, Is it lawful to do good or evil on the sabbath, to save a life or to destroy it? But they were silent.
3.5: And he looked at them with anger, sad because of the hardness of their hearts; and he said to the man, Stretch out your hand, and he stretched it out; and his hand was restored.
3.6: And the Pharisees immediately went out with the Herodians, and they took counsel concerning him how to do away with him.
3.7: So Jesus went to the sea with his disciples; and a great many people from Galilee followed him, and from Judaea,
3.8: And from Jerusalem, and from Idumaea, and from around the Jordan, and from Tyre and from Sidon; large crowds, who had heard all that he was doing, came to him.
3.9: And he said to his disciples to bring the boat near to him, because of the crowds, so that they might not press on him.
3.10: For he was healing so many, that others pushed toward him so as to touch him.
3.11: And those who were afflicted with unclean spirits, when they saw him, fell down before him, and cried saying, You are indeed the Son of God.
3.12: And he cautioned them a great deal, not to make him known.
3.13: And he went up to the mountain, and called those he wanted; and they came to him.
3.14: And he chose twelve to be with him, that he might send them to preach,
3.15: And to have power to heal the sick, and cast out devils.
3.16: And Simon he surnamed Peter.
3.17: And James the son of Zebedee, and John the brother of James, he surnamed Bnai Rakhshi, which means sons of thunder,
3.18: And Andrew, and Philip, and Bartholomew, and Matthew, and Thomas, and James the son of Alphaeus, and Thaddaeus, and Simon the Zealot,
3.19: And Judas of Iscariot, who betrayed him. And they came into the house.
3.20: And the people gathered again, so that they could not find bread to eat.
3.21: And his relatives heard it, and went out to arrest him, for they said, He has lost his mind.
3.22: And the scribes who had come down from Jerusalem said, Beelzebub is with him, and, By the prince of demons he is casting out demons.
3.23: And Jesus called them, and said to them in parables, How can Satan cast out Satan?
3.24: If a kingdom is divided against itself, that kingdom cannot stand.
3.25: And if a household is divided against itself, that household cannot stand.
3.26: And if Satan rises up against himself and is divided, he cannot stand, but that is his end.
3.27: No man can enter into a strong mans house and plunder his goods, unless he first bind the strong man; and then he plunders his house.
3.28: Truly I say to you, that all sins and blasphemies which men blaspheme, shall be forgiven to them.
3.29: But he who blasphemes against the Holy Spirit, shall never be forgiven, but is guilty before the everlasting judgment.
3.30: Because they had said, He has an unclean spirit.
3.31: Then there came his mother and his brothers, and stood outside, and they sent in to call him.
3.32: But the people were sitting around him; and they said to him, Behold, your mother and your brothers are outside, asking for you.
3.33: And he answered and said to them, Who is my mother, and who are my brothers?
3.34: And he looked at those who sat near him and said, Behold my mother, and behold my brothers.
3.35: For whoever does the will of God, is my brother and my sister and my mother.

4.1: AGAIN he began to teach by the sea side; and many people gathered unto him, so that he went up and sat in a boat in the sea; and all the people stood on the land by the sea.
4.2: And he taught them much by parables, and in his teaching he said,
4.3: Listen; Behold, a sower went out to sow.
4.4: And when he had sown, some fell on the roadside, and the fowls came and ate it.
4.5: Other fell upon the rock, where there was not sufficient soil; and it sprung up earlier because the ground was not deep enough;
4.6: But when the sun shone, it was scorched, and because it had no root, it dried up.
4.7: And other fell among thistles, and the thistles sprung up and choked it, and it bore no fruit.
4.8: But other fell in good soil, and it sprung up and grew and bore fruit, some thirty, and some sixty, and some one hundred.
4.9: And he said, He who has ears to hear, let him hear.
4.10: When they were alone by themselves, those who were with him together with the twelve asked him about that parable.
4.11: And Jesus said to them, To you is given to know the mystery of the kingdom of God, but to the outsiders everything has to be explained by parables.
4.12: For seeing they see, and yet do not perceive; and hearing they hear, and yet do not understand; if they return, their sins would be forgiven.
4.13: And he said to them, Do you not know this parable? how then will you know all the parables?
4.14: The sower who sowed, sowed the word.
4.15: Those on the roadside are those in whom the word is sown; and when they have heard it, Satan comes immediately and takes away the word which is sown in their hearts.
4.16: And those which were sown upon the rock, are those who when they have heard the word, immediately receive it with joy;
4.17: And they have no root in themselves, but last for a while; and when trouble or persecution comes because of the word, they soon stumble.
4.18: And those which were sown among thistles are those who have heard the word,
4.19: And the thoughts of this world, and the deception of wealth, and the lusts of other things, enter in and choke the word, and bear no fruit.
4.20: And those which were sown in good soil, are those who hear the word, and receive it and bear fruit, one thirty, and one sixty, and one a hundred.
4.21: And he said to them, Is a lamp brought and put under a basket or under a bed? Is it not put on a lampholder?
4.22: For there is nothing hidden which will not be uncovered; and nothing in secret which will not be revealed.
4.23: If any man has ears to hear, let him hear.
4.24: And he said to them, Take heed what you hear; with what measure you measure it will be measured to you; and increase especially to them who hear.
4.25: For he who has, to him will be given; and he who has not, even that which he has will be taken away from him.
4.26: And he said, Such is the kingdom of God, like a man who casts seed in the ground.
4.27: And he sleeps and rises up night and day, and the seed springs up and grows, while he is not aware of it.
4.28: For the earth causes it to yield fruit; and yet first it becomes a blade of grass, then an ear, and at last a full grain in the ear.
4.29: But when the fruit is ripe, then immediately comes the sickle, because the harvest is ready.
4.30: And he said, To what shall we compare the kingdom of God? and with what parable shall we picture it?
4.31: It is just like a grain of mustard seed, which, when it is sown in the earth, is the smallest of all the seeds on earth.
4.32: But when it is sown, it springs up and becomes greater than all the herbs, and puts forth large branches, so that the birds can settle under their shadow.
4.33: Jesus talked to them with parables as these, such parables as they were able to hear.
4.34: And without parables he did not speak to them; but to his disciples, among themselves, he explained everything.
4.35: On that day, at evening, he said to them, Let us cross over to the landing place.
4.36: And they left the people, and took him away while he was in the boat. And there were other boats with them.
4.37: And there arose a heavy storm and wind, and the waves kept falling into the boat, so that the boat was nearly filled up.
4.38: But Jesus was sleeping on a blanket in the stern of the boat; and they came and roused him and said to him, Teacher, do you not care that we are perishing?
4.39: So he got up, and rebuked the wind, and said to the sea, Peace, be still. And the wind quieted down, and there was a great calm.
4.40: And he said to them, Why are you so fearful? and why do you have no faith?
4.41: And they were exceedingly afraid, and said to each other, Oh, who is this, that even the wind and the sea obey him?

5.1: AND they reached the port on the other side of the sea, in the country of the Gadarenes.
5.2: And as he went out of the boat, he was met by a man from the cemetery, who had an unclean spirit.
5.3: He lived in the cemetery, and no man could bind him in chains;
5.4: Because whenever he was bound with fetters and chains, he broke the chains and cut the fetters, and no man could control him.
5.5: And always, night and day, he was in the cemetery and in the mountains, crying aloud and cutting himself with stones.
5.6: When he saw Jesus from afar, he ran and worshipped him,
5.7: And he cried with a loud voice and said, What have we got together, Jesus, Son of the most high God? I adjure you by God, not to torment me.
5.8: For he said to him, Get out of the man, O you unclean spirit.
5.9: And he asked him, What is your name? And he said to him, Our name is Legion, because we are many.
5.10: And he begged him much that he would not send him out of the country.
5.11: Now there was there, near the mountain a large herd of swine feeding.
5.12: And the lunatics begged him saying, Send us to the swine, that we may attack them.
5.13: And he permitted them. And the lunatics went out, and attacked the swine; and the herd ran to the steep rocks, and fell into the sea; they were about two thousand, and they were drowned in the water.
5.14: And those who fed them, fled, and told it in the city and also in the villages. So they went out to see what had happened.
5.15: And they came to Jesus, and saw the lunatic, clothed and well behaved, and sitting down; even the one who once had the legion within him; and they were afraid.
5.16: And those who saw it told them just how it happened to the lunatic and also to the swine.
5.17: So they began to urge him to leave their border.
5.18: As he went up to the boat, the lunatic begged him to remain with him.
5.19: And he would not permit him, but said to him, Go to your home, to your own people, and tell them what the Lord has done for you, and had mercy on you.
5.20: And he went away, and began to preach in the ten cities about what Jesus had done for him; and they were all surprised.
5.21: When Jesus crossed in the boat to the other side, large crowds again gathered around him, while he was by the sea.
5.22: And there came one of the leaders of the synagogue, whose name was Jairus; and when he saw him, he fell at his feet,
5.23: And he beseeched him much and said to him, My daughter is very seriously ill; come and lay your hand on her, and she will be healed, and live.
5.24: So Jesus went with him; and a large multitude followed him, and they pressed on him.
5.25: And there was a woman who had had the hemorrhage for twelve years,
5.26: Who had suffered much at the hands of many doctors, and had spent everything she had, and was not helped at all, but rather became worse.
5.27: When she heard concerning Jesus, she came through the dense crowd from behind him, and touched his cloak.
5.28: For she said, If I can only touch his cloak, I will live.
5.29: And immediately the hemorrhage was dried up; and she felt in her body that she was healed of her disease.
5.30: Jesus instantly knew that some power had gone out of him; so he turned around to the people and said, Who touched my garments?
5.31: His disciples said to him, You see the people pressing on you, and yet you say, Who touched me?
5.32: And he was looking round to see who had done this.
5.33: But the woman, frightened and trembling, because she knew what had happened to her, came and fell before him and told him the whole truth.
5.34: He said to her, My daughter, your faith has healed you; go in peace, and be healed of your disease.
5.35: While he was still talking, some men came from the house of the leader of the synagogue, saying, Your daughter is dead; why do you trouble the Teacher?
5.36: Jesus heard the word which they spoke, and he said to the leader of the synagogue, Fear not, only believe.
5.37: And he did not permit any man to go with him, except Simon Peter, and James, and John the brother of James.
5.38: And they came to the house of the leader of the synagogue, and he saw them in a tumult, weeping and wailing.
5.39: So he entered and said to them, Why are you excited and crying? The little girl is not dead, but she is asleep.
5.40: And they laughed at him. But Jesus put them all out, and took the little girls father and mother and those who were with him, and he entered where the little girl was laid.
5.41: And he took the little girl by her hand, and said to her, Talitha, koomi, which means, Little girl, rise up.
5.42: And immediately the little girl got up and walked; for she was twelve years old. And they were astonished with a great astonishment.
5.43: But he commanded them that no man should know this; and he told them to give her something to eat.

6.1: AND Jesus went out from thence, and came to his city; and his disciples followed him.
6.2: When the sabbath came, he began to teach in the synagogue, and many who heard him were surprised, and said, Whence did he receive all this? and what wisdom is this which is given to him, that wonders like these are wrought by his hands?
6.3: Is he not the carpenter, the son of Mary, and the brother of James and Joses and Judas and Simon? and behold, are not his sisters here with us? And they denounced him.
6.4: And Jesus said to them, There is no prophet who is insulted, except in his own city, and among his own brothers, and in his own house.
6.5: And he could not perform even a single miracle there, except that he laid his hand on a few sick people and healed them.
6.6: And he wondered at their lack of faith. And he travelled in the villages teaching.
6.7: Then he called his twelve, and began to send them two by two; and he gave them power over the unclean spirits, to cast them out.
6.8: And he commanded them not to take anything for the journey, except a staff only; no bag, no bread, no copper money in their purses;
6.9: But to wear sandals, and not to wear two shirts.
6.10: And he said to them, Whatever house you enter, stay there until you leave that place.
6.11: And whoever will not receive you, nor hear you, when you leave that place, shake off the sand under your feet as a testimony to them. Truly I say to you, It will be easier for Sodom and Gomorrah in the day of judgment than for that city.
6.12: And they went out and preached that they should repent.
6.13: And they cast out many demons, and anointed with oil many who were sick, and they were healed.
6.14: And Herod the king heard about Jesus, for his name was known to him; and he said, John the Baptist has risen from the dead; this is why miracles are worked by him.
6.15: Others said, He is Elijah. And yet others, He is a prophet, just like one of the prophets.
6.16: But when Herod heard it, he said, John, whom I beheaded; it is he who has risen from the dead.
6.17: For this same Herod had sent out and arrested John, and cast him in prison, because of Herodias, wife of his brother Philip, whom he had married.
6.18: For John had said to Herod, It is not lawful for you to marry your brothers wife.
6.19: But Herodias was bitter towards him, and wanted to kill him; but she could not.
6.20: For Herod was afraid of John, because he knew that he was a righteous and holy man, and he guarded him; and he heard that he was doing a great many things, and he heard him gladly.
6.21: Then came a state day, when Herod on his birthday gave a banquet to his officials, and captains, and the leading men of Galilee.
6.22: And the daughter of Herodias entered in and danced, and she pleased Herod and the guests who were with him; and the king said to the little girl, Ask me whatever you wish, and I will give it to you.
6.23: And he swore to her, Whatever you ask me, I will give you, as much as half of my kingdom.
6.24: She went out and said to her mother, What shall I ask him? She said to her, The head of John the Baptist.
6.25: And immediately she entered cautiously to the king, and said to him, I do wish in this very hour that you may give me on a tray the head of John the Baptist.
6.26: And the king was exceedingly sorry; but because of the oaths, and because of the guests, he did not wish to refuse her.
6.27: So the king immediately sent the executioner, and commanded to bring the head of John. And he went and beheaded John in the prison,
6.28: And brought it on a tray and gave it to the girl; and the girl gave it to her mother.
6.29: And when his disciples heard of it, they came and took up his body and buried it in a grave.
6.30: And the apostles gathered together unto Jesus, and told him everything they had done, and what they had taught.
6.31: And he said to them, Come, let us go to the wilderness all alone, and rest awhile; for there were many coming and going, and they had no chance even to eat.
6.32: So they went away in a boat to a desert place by themselves.
6.33: And many people saw them when they were leaving, and they knew them, and from all the cities they hurried by land and reached the place before him.
6.34: And when Jesus went out he saw large crowds, and he had compassion on them, because they were like sheep without a shepherd; and he began to teach them a great many things.
6.35: And when it was getting late, his disciples came up to him and said to him, This is a desert place, and it is getting late;
6.36: Dismiss them, so that they may go away to the farms and villages around us, and buy bread for themselves; for they have nothing to eat.
6.37: He said to them, You give them to eat. They said to him, Shall we go and buy two hundred pennys worth of bread, and give it to them to eat?
6.38: He said to them, Go and see how many loaves of bread you have got here. And when they found out, they said to him, Five loaves of bread and two fish.
6.39: And he commanded them to make everyone sit down in groups on the grass.
6.40: So they sat down in groups, by hundreds and by fifties.
6.41: Then he took the five loaves of bread and the two fish, and he looked up to heaven, and he blessed and broke the loaves of bread, and gave them to his disciples to place before them; and they divided the two fish among them all.
6.42: And they all ate and were satisfied.
6.43: And they took up the fragments of bread, twelve full baskets, and also of the fish.
6.44: And those who ate the bread were five thousand men.
6.45: And immediately he urged his disciples to go up into the boat, and go in advance of him to the port at Bethsaida, while he dismissed the people.
6.46: And when he had dismissed them, he went up to the mountain to pray.
6.47: When evening came, the boat was in the midst of the sea, and he was alone on the land.
6.48: And he saw them struggling as they were rowing, for the wind was against them; and in the fourth watch of the night, Jesus came to them, walking on the water, and he wanted to pass by them.
6.49: But when they saw him walking on the water, they thought it was a false vision, and they cried out;
6.50: For they all saw him and were frightened. And immediately he spoke to them and said, Have courage, it is I, do not be afraid.
6.51: And he went up to them into the boat, and the wind quieted down; and they marvelled exceedingly, and were astonished in themselves.
6.52: For they did not understand the miracle of the loaves of bread, because their hearts were confused.
6.53: And when they had crossed to the port, they came to the land of Gennesaret.
6.54: And when they went out of the boat, the people of that place immediately knew him.
6.55: And they came running throughout that land; and began to bring those who were seriously sick, carrying them in quilt-beds, where they heard he was.
6.56: And wherever he entered into villages and cities, they laid the sick in the streets, and begged him even to touch the edge of his robe; and all who touched him were healed.

7.1: THEN there gathered unto him Pharisees and scribes, who had come from Jerusalem.
7.2: And they saw some of his disciples eating bread with their hands unwashed; and they reproached them.
7.3: For all the Jews, even the Pharisees, unless their hands are washed carefully would not eat, because they strictly observe the tradition of the elders.
7.4: Even the things from the market, if they are not washed, they would not eat them. And there are a great many other things, which they have accepted to obey, such as the washing of cups and pots, and copper utensils, and the bedding of dead men.
7.5: And the scribes and Pharisees asked him, Why do your disciples not walk according to the tradition of the elders, but eat bread with their hands unwashed?
7.6: He said to them, The prophet Isaiah well prophesied about you, O hypocrites, as it is written, This people honor me with their lips, but their heart is far away from me.
7.7: And they worship me in vain, when they teach the doctrines of the commandments of men.
7.8: For you have ignored the commandment of God, and you observe the tradition of men, such as the washing of cups and pots, and a great many other things like these.
7.9: He said to them, Well you do injustice to the commandment of God so as to sustain your own tradition.
7.10: For Moses said, Honor your father and your mother; and he who curses father or mother, let him be put to death.
7.11: But you say, If a man may say to his father or his mother, What is left over is Corban (my offering);
7.12: And yet you do not let him do anything for his father or mother.
7.13: So you dishonor the word of God for the sake of the tradition which you have established; and you do a great many like these.
7.14: Then Jesus called all the people and said to them, Hear me, all of you, and understand.
7.15: There is nothing outside of a man, if it should enter into him, which can defile him; but what goes out of him, that defiles the man.
7.16: Who has ears to hear, let him hear.
7.17: When Jesus entered into the house because of the people, his disciples asked him concerning that parable.
7.18: And he said to them, So even you are puzzled. Do you not know that whatever enters into a man from outside cannot defile him?
7.19: Because it does not enter into his heart, but into his stomach, and then is thrown out through the intestines, thereby purifying the food.
7.20: It is what goes out of man which defiles the man.
7.21: For from within, from the heart of men go out evil thoughts, such as fornication, adultery, theft, murder,
7.22: Extortion, wickedness, deceit, lust, an evil eye, blasphemy, pride, foolishness;
7.23: All these evils go out from within, and they defile the man.
7.24: Jesus moved away from thence, and came to the borders of Tyre and Sidon, and he entered into a house, and did not want any one to know about him. And yet he could not hide himself.
7.25: For immediately a woman heard about him, whose daughter had an unclean spirit; and she came and fell at his feet.
7.26: But the woman was a heathen, from Phoenicia in Syria; and she besought him to cast out the demon from her daughter.
7.27: And Jesus said to her, Let the children be first filled; for it is not right to take the childrens bread and throw it to the dogs.
7.28: But she answered and said to him, Yes, my Lord; even the dogs eat the childrens crumbs under the trays.
7.29: Jesus said to her, Go your way; just because of this word, the demon has gone out of your daughter.
7.30: So she went to her house, and found her daughter lying in bed, and the demon gone out of her.
7.31: Again Jesus went out from the border of Tyre and Sidon, and came to the sea of Galilee, to the border of the ten cities.
7.32: And they brought to him a deaf and dumb man; and they asked him to lay his hand on him.
7.33: So he drew him aside from the people, and put his fingers into his ears, then he spat, and touched his tongue;
7.34: And he looked up to heaven, and sighed, and he said to him, Ethpatakh, which means, Be opened.
7.35: And in that very hour his ears were opened, and the knot of his tongue was loosened, and he spoke plainly.
7.36: And he warned them not to tell this to any man; but the more he warned them, so much the more they published it.
7.37: And they were greatly astonished, saying, He does everything so well. He makes the deaf hear, and the dumb to speak.

8.1: IN those days, when there was a large multitude, and they had nothing to eat, he called his disciples and said to them,
8.2: I have pity for this people, for they have remained with me three days, and they have nothing to eat;
8.3: And if I dismiss them to their homes, while they are fasting, they will faint on the way, for some of them have come from a distance.
8.4: His disciples said to him, How can any man here in this lonely place, feed all of these with bread?
8.5: And he asked them, How many loaves have you? They said to him, Seven.
8.6: So he commanded the people to sit on the ground; and he took the seven loaves of bread, and he blessed them, and broke them, and gave them to his disciples to set before them; and they set them before the people.
8.7: And there were a few fishes; he blessed them also, and commanded to set them before them.
8.8: So they ate and were satisfied, and they took up seven baskets of fragments which were left over.
8.9: The men who ate were about four thousand; and he dismissed them.
8.10: And immediately he went up into the boat with his disciples, and he came to the country of Dalmanutha.
8.11: And the Pharisees came out and began to question him, and they asked him for a sign from heaven, so as to test him.
8.12: And he sighed in his spirit and said, Why does this generation want a sign? truly I say to you, No sign will be given to this generation.
8.13: And he left them, and went up into the boat, and departed from that port.
8.14: And they had forgotten to take bread; except one loaf they had none with them in the boat.
8.15: And he commanded them and said to them, Look out, and beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and of the leaven of Herod.
8.16: They were reasoning among themselves and saying, It is because we have no bread.
8.17: But Jesus knew it and said to them, What are you thinking, because you have no bread? Do you not even yet know, and do you not understand? Is your heart still hard?
8.18: You have eyes, and yet do you not see? You have ears, and yet do you not hear? And do you not remember?
8.19: When I broke the five loaves of bread for the five thousand, how many full baskets of fragments did you take up? They said to him, Twelve.
8.20: He said to them, And when the seven for the four thousand, how many baskets full of fragments did you take up? They said, Seven.
8.21: He said to them, How is it then that even yet you cannot understand?
8.22: And he came to Bethsaida; and they brought to him a blind man, and they besought him to touch him.
8.23: And he took the blind man by the hand and brought him outside the town; and he spat on his eyes, and put his hands on him, and asked him what he saw.
8.24: And he looked and said, I see men like trees, walking.
8.25: Again he put his hands over his eyes, and he was restored, and saw everything clearly.
8.26: And he sent him to his house, saying, Do not enter even into the town, nor tell it to anyone in the town.
8.27: And Jesus went out, and his disciples, to the towns of Caesarea of Philippi; and on the road he asked his disciples and said to them, What do men say about me, that I am?
8.28: They said, John the Baptist; and others, Elijah; and yet others, One of the prophets.
8.29: Jesus said to them, But you, who do you say I am? Simon Peter answered and said to him, You are the Christ, the Son of the living God.
8.30: And he warned them not to tell any man about him.
8.31: Then he began to teach them, that the Son of man will have to suffer a great deal, and be rejected by the elders, and the high priests, and the scribes, and be killed, and rise again on the third day.
8.32: And he spoke that word openly. So Peter took him aside and began to rebuke him.
8.33: But he turned around and looked on his disciples, and he rebuked Simon, and said, Get behind me, Satan; for you are not thinking the things of God, but of men.
8.34: And Jesus called the people together with his disciples, and said to them, He who wishes to come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.
8.35: For whoever wishes to save his life will lose it; and whoever loses his life for my sake and the sake of my Gospel, he will save it.
8.36: For how could a man be benefited, if he should gain the whole world and lose his life?
8.37: Or what could a man give in exchange for his life?
8.38: Whoever, therefore, is ashamed of me and of my words in this sinful and adulterous generation, the Son of man will also be ashamed of him, when he comes in the glory of his Father with his holy angels.

9.1: AND he said to them, Truly I say to you, that there are men standing here, who shall not taste death, till they see that the kingdom of God has come with power.
9.2: And six days after, Jesus took Peter, and James, and John, and brought them up to a high mountain alone; and he was transfigured before their eyes.
9.3: His clothes shone, and became white like snow, in such a manner that men on earth cannot make white.
9.4: And there appeared to them Moses and Elijah, talking with Jesus.
9.5: And Peter said to him, Teacher, it is better for us to remain here; and let us make three shelters, one for you, and one for Moses, and one for Elijah.
9.6: For he did not know what he was saying, for they were in fear.
9.7: And there was a cloud overshadowing them, and a voice out of the cloud said, This is my beloved Son; hear him.
9.8: And suddenly, when the disciples looked around, they saw no man, except Jesus alone with them.
9.9: And as they came down from the mountain, he commanded them not to tell any man what they had seen, until the Son of man has risen from the dead.
9.10: So they kept that saying to themselves, and they wanted to know what risen from the dead means.
9.11: And they asked him, saying, Why then do the scribes say that Elijah must first come?
9.12: He said to them, Elijah does come first, to prepare everything; and as it is written concerning the Son of man, that he will suffer much and be rejected.
9.13: But I say to you, that Elijah has also come, and they did with him whatever they pleased, as it is written of him.
9.14: And when he came to his disciples, he saw a large crowd with them, and the scribes debating with them.
9.15: And immediately all the people saw him, and were greatly surprised, and they ran to greet him.
9.16: And he asked the scribes, What do you debate with them?
9.17: One of the multitude answered and said, Teacher, I brought my son to you, for he has a spirit of dumbness.
9.18: And whenever it seizes him, it troubles him; and he foams, and gnashes his teeth, and gets worn out. And I asked your disciples to cast it out, but they could not.
9.19: Jesus answered and said to him, O faithless generation, how long shall I be with you? and how long shall I preach to you? bring him to me.
9.20: And they brought the boy to Jesus; and when the spirit seized him, it immediately troubled him; and he fell on the ground, gasping and foaming.
9.21: So Jesus asked his father, How long has he been like this? He said to him, From his childhood.
9.22: And many times it has thrown him into the fire and into the water to destroy him; but whatever you can do, help me, and have mercy on me.
9.23: Jesus said to him, If you can believe, everything is possible to him who believes.
9.24: And immediately the father of the boy cried out weeping, and said, I do believe, help my little belief.
9.25: When Jesus saw that people were run- ning and gathering to him, he rebuked the unclean spirit, and said to it, O deaf and dumb spirit, I command you, come out of him, and do not enter him again.
9.26: And the epileptic cried out much, and was tortured, and the spirit went out; then the boy became as if dead, so that many could say, He is dead.
9.27: Then Jesus took him by the hand, and lifted him up.
9.28: When Jesus entered the house, his disciples asked him privately, Why could we not cast it out?
9.29: He said to them, This kind cannot be cast out by anything, except by fasting and prayer.
9.30: And when they went out from thence, they passed through Galilee; and he did not want any man to know about him.
9.31: For he taught his disciples, and said to them, The Son of man will be delivered into the hands of men, and they will kill him; and after he is killed, he will rise on the third day.
9.32: But they did not understand the saying, and they were afraid to ask him.
9.33: And they came to Capernaum; and when they entered the house, he asked them, What were you reasoning among yourselves on the road?
9.34: But they kept silent, for on the road they had argued with one another, which was the greatest of them.
9.35: And Jesus sat down, and he called the twelve and said to them, He who wishes to be first, let him be the last of every man, and the minister of every man.
9.36: And he took a little boy, and made him to stand in the midst; then he took him in his arms, and said to them,
9.37: Whoever receives a boy like this in my name, he receives me; and he who receives me, does not receive me, but him who has sent me.
9.38: John said to him, Teacher, we saw a man casting out demons in your name; and we forbade him, because he did not follow us.
9.39: Jesus said to them, Do not forbid him; for there is no man who performs miracles in my name, who will hastily speak evil of me.
9.40: Therefore, he who is not against you is for you.
9.41: For whoever gives you to drink even a cup of water only, because you represent the name of Christ, truly I say to you that his reward shall not be lost.
9.42: And whoever shall cause one of these little ones who believe in me to stumble, it were better for him that an ass mill stone were hanged on his neck and then he were thrown into the sea.
9.43: If your hand offends you, cut it off; it is much better for you to go through life maimed, than to have two hands and go to Gehenna,
9.44: Where their worm does not die, and their fire does not quench.
9.45: And if your foot offends you, cut it off; it is much better for you to go through life lame, than to have two feet, and fall into Gehenna,
9.46: Where their worm does not die, and their fire does not quench.
9.47: And if your eye offends you, remove it; it is better for you to enter the kingdom of God with one eye, than to have two eyes and fall into the Gehenna of fire,
9.48: Where their worm does not die, and their fire does not quench.
9.49: For everything will be salted on fire, and every sacrifice will be salted with salt.
9.50: O how good is salt; but if the salt should lose its savor, with what could it be salted? Let there be salt in you, and be in peace with one another.

10.1: AND he departed from thence, and came to the border of Judaea, at the crossing of the Jordan; and a great many people went to him there, and he taught them again, as he was accustomed to do.
10.2: And the Pharisees came up to him, tempting him and asking, Is it lawful for a man to desert his wife?
10.3: He said to them, What did Moses command you?
10.4: They said, Moses gave us permission to write a letter of separation, and then to divorce.
10.5: Jesus answered and said to them, It was because of the hardness of your heart, that he wrote for you this particular law.
10.6: But from the very beginning God made them male and female.
10.7: For this reason a man shall leave his father and his mother and follow his wife.
10.8: And both shall be one flesh; henceforth they are not two, but one flesh.
10.9: What therefore God has joined, let no man separate.
10.10: And his disciples again asked him about this in the house.
10.11: And he said to them, Whoever divorces his wife and marries another, commits adultery.
